issues.summary: Dynamic Admin-tables interface
issues.description:
(Trying out the GitHub issue tracker)
The admin interfaces for the Dynamic tables stuff seems to be missing.

When we merged Stephan's code for provenance we seemed to have missed the admin stuff for the tables whose names start with 'dynamic_model'.

I also don't understand how these fit in to the scheme of things but it seems that we have an omission.

comments.body:
No, there was never any admin stuff for the dynamic_models app. There is a bit of magic (monkey patching) going on here which we could (should) probably get rid of, and would cause less confusion later if we did.

He kept the dynamic_models application as a separate application that contains the dynamic_models code. Then the provenance app was added as a wrapper on the top to link the dynamic_models app into kea. The models in the dynamic_models app are monkey patched to appear like they are part of the provenance app. The DynamicModel model is actually appears in the django admin called "Provenance definitions" under the provenance app. Ping me on gtalk if you want me to explain it in more detail.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
I removed the magic William talked about to make it simpler and all is now in the provenance application.

Hope that William explained how the "dynamic models" fit into the scheme of things and all is becoming slowly less confusing.

issues.summary: mechanism for attaching samples to provenances
issues.description:
Although the provenance system seems to be coming into shape nicely, we have forgotten a vital step.

We need to figure out how we attach a given provenance to a sample.
The present pedigree provenance for a sample is via a column on the sample table that is a foreign key to a plant.

This will not work for our new system. 
How do we attach a provenance to a sample?
Perhaps some sort of many to many where one half of the many to many defines which provenance is to be attached?

I am fairly certain that we will need to change the sample table so that the Plant column is no longer "not null" but maybe we need to add one or two columns to get that connection or just do it via the aforementioned many to many.

comments.body: That's what the ProvenanceType table is for. There should be a ForeignKey on the Sample table which links to the ProvenanceType table. If you read my original spec this was all covered. The idea was a nullable ForeignKey to the Plant table and a ForeignKey to the ProvenanceType table. Then when/if the new Provenance code consumes the pedigree data we can remove the Plant ForeignKey from the Sample table.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Just thinking about this I think that the relationship is many to one.
Multiple samples could conceivably have one provenance, but I don't think that a sample should have more than one provenance.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: My solution already does exactly this. Each Sample can only ever have one ProvenanceType and a ProvenanceType can have many samples.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
To use the provenance type table for this we will still need some way of identifying which field of what provenance to use.

So I'm not sure that what Stephan has created will fit with that model as he has made the provenance type a way of grouping provenances.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: Not sure exactly what you mean by the first paragraph. Would be easier to discuss this on hangout rather than here I think.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Current thinking on this is as follows:

Samples will be linked to provenances using a many-to-many defined on the dynamic model.

This many-to-many will have to be a many-to-many using a "through" table

ManyToManyField(Sample, through='SomeProvenanceJoiningTable')

We require the through table because the foreign key to the sample table must be unique. The "through" table looks like this

class SomeProvenanceJoiningTable(models.Model)
some_provenance_joining_table = models.ManyToManyField('ProvenanceTable')
sample = models.ManyToManyField('Sample', unique=True)

This allows us to have the database managing relational data integrity rather than using the GenericForeignKey implementation that django provides.

There is one problem with this solution linking samples to provenances
there will be multiple m2m joining tables from sample to provenance
each one of those joining tables has a unique sample_id column
but it's only unique over one table, not across multiple joining tables
this means that is is actually still possible to have a sample attached to more than one provenance
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
What you describe in code is not a through table. Not sure the samples are all in the same table but if they are could it be possible to use a shared through table for this?

With the dynamic model you can create this ...

``` python
class SharedProvenanceMapping(models.Model):
    sample = models.ForeignKey('app.Sample', unique=True, null=False, blank=False, index=True)
    provenance1 = models.ForeignKey('provenance.First', null=True, blank=True, index=True)
    provenance2 = models.ForeignKey('provenance.Second, null=True, blank=True, index=True)
    ...

class First(models.Model):
    samples = models.ManyToManyField('app.Sample', through='shared.SharedProvenanceMapping')
    ...

class Second(models.Model):
    samples = models.ManyToManyField('app.Sample', through='shared.SharedProvenanceMapping')
    ...
```

The model still allows samples to be attached to >1 provenance, though the way the Django ORM works this should never be a problem. The problem I see is that through tables change the behaviour of the [ORM](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.6/topics/db/models/#intermediary-manytomany) and I can see many problems with them and a dynamic model/admin/import & export approach.

A possible solution, that needs more thought, might be a custom M2M field that always uses the same through table in the way I described, but does not change the default ORM M2M behaviour. The field could filter out sample ids that already have associations, avoiding unique constraint exceptions that would defo pop up otherwise.

Any thoughts?

comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Just thinking about, it we can modify this so that the provenance table is a foreign key to the dynamic_models_dynamicmodel table and just use the trigger for checking the provenance id column.
But I think that the idea is sound.
Can anybody see anything wrong with it?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: Good to know that the idea worked. Now that we have a working example at the database level we could possibly look at a custom implementation of django's GenericForeignKey to work with this at the ORM level.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body: I think that we have nailed this now
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Crop style filtering of data for provenances
issues.description:
We need to create a system for ensuring that a user can only see data for a given provenance a la crops.

We will need a way of selecting which provenance the user wants to see data for and a mechanism for controlling who has access to what provenance.

This should really be done before we go live properly but for the initial roll-out for Marc Greven (Suavignon Blanc) we can probably live without it.

We can just use his access to funny-fruit and he can muddle through.

comments.body: The access should probably just be given via the app
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Haven't looked much into the way Kea does user permissions and how they 
are handled with the integration of the admin. In a perfect world 
situation I can create the default model permissions (change, delete, 
add) in auth.permissions for dynamic models and if you remove all those 
permissions for a user he wont have access to them at all.

Can anyone comment on the way the admin stuff is integrated into Kea?

On Di 13 Mai 2014 21:15:52 PDT, Zane Gilmore wrote:

> The access should probably just be given via the app
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/issues/10#issuecomment-43040553.

Currently there is a CropUser model that maps users to crops. It handles which crops a user has access to. Have a look at the crop app in kea. It contains the form for choosing crops and a middleware that sets the request.crop property. This is a rewrite of Zane's original crop handling code.

issues.description:
I have created Prov tables with json e.g.:

---

{
  "to":"sauv_blanc.Company",
  "to_field":"name"
}

---

But when I try to add a row into that table using the name field I get:

---

Line number: 1 - invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'Acme Wines'

Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/home/zane/programming/virtenv/kea/eggs/django_import_export-0.2.2-py2.7.egg/import_export/resources.py", line 335, in import_data
self.import_obj(instance, row, real_dry_run)

issues.summary: Datagrid sorting is not working
issues.description:
When I do an order by LocalID and set them to 50 records at a time then look thru the pages, the pages do not not match with the choose widget which I do the same on.

It appears to be a sorting issue:

```
Old Choose  New Datagrid
POP0Y1D POP0Y1D
POP0Y26     POP0Y2K
POP0Y2K     POP0Y26
POP0Y46     POP0Y46
POP0Y47     POP0Y47
POP0Y48     POP0Y49
POP0Y49     POP0Y48
POP0Y6W POP0Y6Y
POP0Y6Y     POP0Y6Z
POP0Y6Z     POP0Y6W
```

As you can see my old choose widget seems to be getting it right.
But the datagrid seems to shuffling things up.

comments.body: I suspect what is happening is your choose widget is ordering by localid in the database when the localid is being stored as an integer. I'm storing the localid as a base32 encoded string and it's trying to order on that. That would explain the problem? It's the only thing I can think of. The solution would be to store the local id as an integer in elasticsearch then post process it before displaying it in the datagrid. This does add extra overhead in processing time because some of those local id's require database queries to render. That's overhead that we're trying to avoid.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body: But if you store it as an integer how are you supposed to filter on it? So that won't work. I have no idea how to solve this at the moment. Any ideas are welcome.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
William,
As far as I can tell the base32 and the integer should sort in the same order.
I can't see why it shouldn't
If you look at the entries I listed above they are not in the correct order for either integer or base32
To me it looks like something else is going wrong.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Entries not added after sample initialisation
issues.description:
When I initialised a (single pop) batch none of:
genotype
plant
or sample 
had the new entries added to the datagrid.
The new rows **were** added to the DB.

comments.body:
The code is trying to update them in the index. The problem is that Creating a new sample batch happens in a single transaction. The post_save model signals are sent when the model is saved but the record is unable to be retrieved from the database until the transaction is submitted. That means that most of the records won't be updated in elasticsearch because the code tries to populate elasticsearch before the transaction is committed and fails because the data in the database isn't available yet.

No ideas yet how to solve this problem. It's a tricky one.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
The following issue seems to be relevant https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/14051

Django 1.6 has new improved transaction management. This should be investigated as a possible solution.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body: Also https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/21803 and https://github.com/carljm/django-transaction-hooks
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Fixed this by using https://github.com/davehughes/django-transaction-signals

We will need to refactor kea/elasticsearch/signals.py when we upgrade to django 1.6.

Use this library https://django-transaction-hooks.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

We can quite easily upgrade between the two by doing something like

```
connection.on_commit(lambda: some_celery_task.delay('arg1'))
```
comments.author: will.buick

issues.summary: Provenence import does not handle dates
issues.description:
I have tried everything.
I have tried to upload the data formatted as date values, and as strings.

There does not seem to be any way of structuring the data in any way that is acceptable.
If I upload it as date it complains that it wants a string not a float.

If I structure it as a string then it complains it is not in the right format.
This will not work.

comments.body:
Did some research about this to figure out what is going on. With the 
information Zane gave me that dates are stored in excel as integers I 
found this post http://www.cpearson.com/excel/datetime.htm . This isn't 
ideal but since we are the creating source for the excel workbook I 
feel it is save to assume that dates start from 1900 NOT 1904.

On Di 24 Jun 2014 21:14:12 PDT, Zane Gilmore wrote:

>

> format.
> This will not work.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/issues/42.

Stefan,
xlrd and xlwt should do the date handling for you. (import/export should
too)
The main thing is that you know what the the type of the cell _should_ be
and are duly dealt with.

I have had a great deal of trouble dealing with Excel dates too.
If you have a look at pndata/processExcel.py line 1731 -> line 1794 you can
get a insight into the painful world of importing date data from
spreadsheets.

Feel free to create a decent method for extracting dates from a known date
cell using this code as a starting point.

Note the use of "xldate_as_tuple()" on line 1780 which IIRC is in xlrd

Also the regex for pulling apart strings (line 1749) is pretty primitive
too but it works most of the time :-/

issues.summary: renaming column appears to just add new column in DB
issues.description:
When I changed the name of a column in a prov table the column was was not changed and there was a new column added to the DB with the same attributes as the old except for the name.

The export spreadsheet does not include the old column so when an import is attempted you get a postgres error saying that the entry contains an illegal null.
(I assume that this does not occur for a nullable column)

comments.body:
Yeah I am not surprised. A rename will look for the migration 
introspection like a delete and add. In a normal application lifecycle, 
on would alter the migration to do a rename not a delete/add to not 
lose data but with the dynamic-on-the-fly-approach I consider this an 
edge case that should be avoided.

 From our earlier talks I took that alter tables are something you 
hardly ever do and the system should not put much emphasis on alter 
table functionality (except add column).

Will have to think about a way to fix this.

issues.description:
OK,
the problem is that the altname that we are creating from the EBrida Group column is creating an AltName that is longer than 50 chars

There are 2 routes we can take here:
- Increase the size limit in the DB to, say, 100 chars: This has a potentially practical problem where the altname should be a unique identifier for the given entity. Should it ever be over 50chars? How much more complicated will it make the rollout to the servers?
- Reduce the size of the created altname: Will this mean the altname has less value? Will it have less usable data?

comments.body:
I am inclined to go for the expansion of the altname field.
I think that the rollout should not be too complicated.

Marek Kuziel // Encode Ltd

issues.summary: location does not exist error when trying to delete altname for plant
issues.description:
When you click on the pencil in browse Plants and try to delete an altname you just get an error complaining about the location for the plant not existing. 
And the altname is not deleted.

comments.body:
Finally tracked this one down. Bug is as follows:

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/blob/master/src/kea/kea/pndata/models.py#L505

See limit_choices_to

And here in the admin form

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/blob/master/src/kea/kea/pndata/admin.py#L182

The form allows all locations but the model is restricting plant locations to those that match the filters in the limit_choices_to dicton save. Obviously this Plant has a location that does not match those filters. I'm not sure how that happened. It shouldn't be possible unless creating or updating the plant using raw sql.

There are different ways to fix this.

1) Either we remove the limit_choices_to dict and allow a plant to have any location. 
2) We update the PlantAdminForm and filter the locations queryset with those same limit_choice_to dict filters.

2 does not actually fix the problem because the location would still not be valid, it would just show a more useful error message. Also, another problem with 2 is that specific locations would be unvalid but the user would still be able to choose those invalid locations with the datagrid and would not be informed the location is invalid until the form is saved. To fix the problem using 2 and do it properly is actually rather difficult.

I'll wait and hear your thoughts on this.

There are many ways to apply a location to a plant.
The most common one is via the batch file upload mechanism.

This means that any plant location-type that can be chosen from the "Location Type for Plant" drop-down can be applied to a plant.

If we are going to restrict location types anywhere then we should be able to apply location-types everywhere. This means we will need to have a means of creating sets of location-types.
And _that_ means that we need to create two new tables:
- a location-type-set table 
- and a many to many to location-type.

Then we can ensure that only location-types from a particular set are allowed in particular contexts.
I do believe that we will eventually need this but right now it would be just too much.

So...
Option 1 is the correct one for now.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: after deleting a plant (or anything) returning to the unfiltered list
issues.description:
If the user deletes a sample or plant or whatever from the view data area the page that is returned to is the unfiltered datagrid for the entity.

This needs to be set to return back to the same page that the user was working in.

comments.body: Added with 9b82028b05a7eb6e21fe319b7b2ffc2d5200db9b

However ... on delete and return to filtered datagrid: the item deleted still shows in the grid because it has not yet been deleted from elasticsearch index.

Possible solution: On single item deletion act immediately to delete from index instead of passing to a deferred celery task.  Caution: On deletion of say, a population, many items will be deleted (plants, genotypes and sample) maybe causing a bottleneck (?).

Does anyone see any issue with **not** deferring to celery a deletion from elasticsearch index. I've tried it out on my local box without any problem and it solves the issue I describe in my previous comment. In the scenario where a user is deleting a single item at a time then I don't see a problem. However if hundreds (or thousands) are deleted in a single action then it could have an impact. Comments?

You would need some way of checking how many index entries are to be deleted for that one deletion.
Then a threshhold value for deciding whether to defer to celery or not.

I am inclined to say that this is a good idea. Especially for genotypes, plants, samples and sample-extracts.
Basically for entities that are reasonably stand-alone. Populations might be a bit problematic as there could potentially be thousands of attached genotypes etc. (commonly hundreds)

This also means that perhaps we should identify which entities can be deleted or even modified or created without deferring to celery.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Yes. Good summary of my own thoughts. I also noted Populations as being problematic (having deleted a couple and seeing how many connected objects there are).

Because `delete_from_elasticsearch` gets called from the `delete_model` signal a simple solution could be:

```
if isinstance(instance, Population):
    defer(delete_from_elasticsearch.delay, get_model_identifier(instance))
else:
    delete_from_elasticsearch(get_model_identifier(instance))
```

Does django trigger delete signals for all related data when deleting a population? or does it let the database preform deletions using database constraints? If django doesn't trigger delete signals for related models (eg it's done at database level) then it's not a problem.

I believe that the delete signal is called on all objects deleted in the cascade, in fact it must be otherwise the index will be out of sync with the database.

I just tried deleting a population with over 100 related objects without deferring to celery with no perceivable performance hit when being returned to the datagrid view. Checked my indices for plant, genotype, samples etc and all has been updated correctly.
It looks like this was not addressed. And probably should be.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

Most recent commit at time of writing: 2b456cd642de3b7c293ed2f458a2e60f29e05bd9

Doctests cover most of this (haven't tried to get `make coverage` working). Standing unit tests run without errors and I've done a fair bit of user testing acting within both crop and provenance. Here's a list of stuff that I see as working now on the provenance branch.
- initialise sample batch
- create process run
- view and select process runs
- view and search plates
- view and search batch spreadsheets with filtered columns

In user testing I find that in stepping through processes in a process run errors arise because the process expects a plant (or population or genotype). I'm certainly at the point to be working on process runs and sorting these problems out.

I'm using keadbdev_20140909 as my database dump before running migrate. I've gained a bit of control over my elasticsearch instance with 3rd party plugins but still come across problems that I solve by deleting and rebuilding the indices.

Cheers,
Darryl

comments.body:
I've found these plugins very useful for having a look at the indices. HQ gives an immediate overview of the status and a list of indices, counts, shards, nodes, etc as well as other screens for checking all aspects of the cluster - filesystem use, cache and memory use etc. Inquisitor has less bells and whistles but I like its simpler interface for making practice json queries. 

https://github.com/royrusso/elasticsearch-HQ

```
  $ plugin -install royrusso/elasticsearch-HQ
  $ open http://localhost:9200/_plugin/HQ/
```

https://github.com/polyfractal/elasticsearch-inquisitor

```
  $ plugin -install polyfractal/elasticsearch-inquisitor
  $ open http://localhost:9200/_plugin/inquisitor/
```

Have you tried re-populating that index alone?

```
$ django populate_index plant-data-for-search
```

The single index took about 15-20 mins on my machine. I don't know if that is possible on the production instance (performance wise).

The trouble is that the problem is on at least genotypes and samples as well.
However I suppose that we could see whether the index is re-created properly.

issues.summary: Speeding up indexing
issues.description:
Hi All,

I've looked at the `extract_document` method of `SampleMappingType` because it is my assumption that this is where the bottleneck is. The result for 100 samples with the old method is:

```
>>> reset_queries()
>>> def make_docs_old():
...     for sample in Sample.objects.all():
...         doc = SampleMappingType.extract_document(sample)
>>> timeit.timeit(make_docs, number=10)
13.682330131530762
>>> len(connection.queries)
14010
```

And my new method:

```
>>> reset_queries()
>>> def make_docs_new():
...     for sample in Sample.objects.all():
...         doc = SampleMappingType.new_extract(sample)
>>> timeit.timeit(make_docs, number=10)
3.682511920928955
>>> len(connection.queries)
1010
```

There is some small variations in the results but the new method takes consistently around 30% of the time.

I spent around 3 hours on the method (and I need some more testing to ensure that I'm correctly indexing altnames in particular).

I estimate then around 3-4 hours per mapping type (of which there are 9 in total).

Is this worth me doing?

The other point of optimisation could also be updagrading to Django 1.6 which will also help. From William:

From what I've read this is what Django uses to check for the existence of a particular record. I mentioned this earlier about how django preforms a select before update. This is silly and the behaviour actually changed in Django 1.6.

Cheers,
Darryl

comments.body:
Further to yesterdays note I've had a look at optimising at the task level with these results:

## Elasticsearch Indexing

Imports::

```
>>> from kea.elasticsearch.utils.models import get_model_identifier
>>> from kea.elasticsearch.tasks import update_elasticsearch
>>> from kea.elasticsearch.tasks import update_elasticsearch_new
```

old method::

```
>>> def make_docs():
...     for sample in Sample.objects.all():
...         reset_queries()
...         model_identifier = get_model_identifier(sample)
...         update_elasticsearch(model_identifier)
>>> t1 = timeit.timeit(make_docs, number=10)
>>> len(connection.queries)
27
```

New method::

```
>>> def make_docs():
...     for sample in Sample.objects.all():
...         reset_queries()
...         model_identifier = get_model_identifier(sample)
...         update_elasticsearch_new(model_identifier)
>>> t2 = timeit.timeit(make_docs, number=10)
>>> len(connection.queries)
3
```

Time spent better than 25% of the old method (within 20-22% on repeated runs of
the test)::

```
>>> int(t2/t1*100) < 25
True
```

## Elasticsearch Bulk Indexing

Imports::

```
>>> from kea.elasticsearch.tasks import bulk_index_elasticsearch
>>> from kea.elasticsearch.tasks import bulk_index_elasticsearch_new
```

Create the batch of model identifiers::

```
>>> batch = [get_model_identifier(mod) for mod in Sample.objects.all()]
```

Wrap the methods to pass arguments to timeit::

```
>>> def wrapper(func, *args, **kwargs):
...     def wrapped():
...         return func(*args, **kwargs)
...     return wrapped
```

Old method::

```
>>> reset_queries()
>>> wrapped = wrapper(bulk_index_elasticsearch, *batch)
>>> t1 = timeit.timeit(wrapped, number=10)
>>> print(len(connection.queries)/10)
270
```

New method::

```
>>> reset_queries()
>>> wrapped = wrapper(bulk_index_elasticsearch_new, *batch)
>>> t2 = timeit.timeit(wrapped, number=10)
>>> print(len(connection.queries)/10)
11
```

Time spent ranges from 4-7% of the old method on repeated runs of the test
(benefits increase with the number of items indexed)::

```
>>> int(t2/t1*100) < 10
True
```

issues.summary: New Update processrun form could be disastrous
issues.description:
Because of the way you are now editing the processrun data in the UpdateProcessRunView method we are going to have to either ensure that the processrun has not been processed at all and had data input into it. Or we need to NOT edit the processrun by first deleting all sampleprocess rows, as is now being done.

Editing a processrun has always been a bit problematic but this would be disastrous if someone edited one after they had entered data.

What I suggest is: that we do a check on the processrun to see that it hasn't been processed at all with uploaded data before we allow updates. This will be a lot easier. 
It will mean that, at least, people can fix their initial mistakes.

In the long run we can either allow for addition of new samples and just add them or delete samples carefully, recursively working our way through the processrun structure.
But this is likely to take a lot of effort to do right.

(this test writing looks useful already :-) )

issues.summary: Setting up the permission system for provenances
issues.description:
I am not sure that I can set up a user to have full access to the admin interfaces for the provenance tables right now.
Do we need to set up some pages that we can give users access to those admin pages for the dynamic tables?

This is the ability to be able add rows into the dynamic tables etc not to change the tables.

They will need to be able to access them but I don't want to have to give them full access.
The dynamic tables are not listed in the "Available Permissions" list in the "Change group" form.

So how do we do this?

comments.body:
Two approaches 'off the top of my head':
1. Dynamically set up a new set of permissions when a provenance dynamic table is created.
2. Add interface to manually set up new set of permissions for each/any provenance table.

I see both as being equal tasks (i.e. one not easier than the other) therefore I'd propose 1.

I agree with Darryl re going for no.1, although no.2 sounds like a more generic solution which could be used later on for changing the permissions if required. 

Currently we only need to worry about Sauvignon Blanc provenance tables which simplifies the task for now.

One way or another neither of the proposed ways sound like an easy one. We should discuss this properly before we start doing anything.

PS: I disagree with this issue being labeled as "UI bug", because AFAIK there isn't any error that would make this a bug. The feature is simply missing completely rather than UI has a bug in it.

When I think about it Marek, you are right.
It's not a UI bug.
And yes it's definitely a good idea to talk about this.
I get the impression Marek that you think that this is a more significant issue than I first thought.

comments.body:
No, I get it now. I note also that the Person sheet also includes the Audit fields - not desirable.

This is because when the code creates the import/export Resource for a model in this situation it does its best to evaluate the fields on the model. For Biomarker I was customising each Resource almost on a per model basis to get fine-grained control over it. A possible solution would be to create a PersonResource.

However, I'm still having serious doubts about using this multi-sheet import for creating the (e.g) 'harvest samples' in sample initialisation. I do understand that it is a better workflow for users to have a single multisheet spreadsheet rather than forcing them to sort out their companies, trial plots, vineyard blocks etc through /provenance/admin/ **before** sample initialisation but this will certainly be a more robust solution. What do you think?

When I built the sample initialisation widget I allowed for users to upload a multi-sheet excel file with data loaded for all relevant tables in the provenance, i.e. company -> vineyard -> vineyardblock -> harvest. 

The vineyard for example will have a foreign key to a company and my code allowed for the company to be created, vineyards created etc all on the same upload. Later a request was made for a 'custom' admin for a provenance which gives the user excel upload for each of the tables individually and avoids the problems of creating objects on the fly. I added a note on github for this issue suggesting that the multisheet upload on sample initialisation be dumped and only having the single sheet for say 'harvest' import to initialise samples (as for example the crop sample initialisation).

OK,
Just trying to upload batch file for a provenance.
am getting this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/home/zane/programming/virtenv/kea/src/kea/kea/provenance/views/initialisation.py", line 164, in process_step
dryrun=False)
File "/home/zane/programming/virtenv/kea/src/kea/kea/provenance/excel/utils.py", line 100, in import_provenance_definition
dataset, dry_run=dryrun, raise_errors=raise_errors)
IntegrityError: null value in column "trial_plot_id" violates not-null constraint
DETAIL: Failing row contains (10, null, 2015, null, 2014-10-01, null, null, null, , null, null, null, null, 1.10, null, null, 6).

An import error occurred, please return to the previous step and check the fields in the spreadsheet, especially those that are referencing by name objects not yet created. 
```

This appears to be because I am trying to create a "Cultivationdetail " row that uses a foreign key to a row defined elsewhere in the spreadsheet.
That row for a trial plot has not yet been inserted into the table so the DB throws a constraint violation.

What is needed is a bit of applied graph theory.
You need to create a tree structure of each of the classes/tables starting with the provenance list object at the root.
Each child from the root describes a referential constraint.
Then you use this tree structure to decide the order of the inserts into the DB.
You do a depth first search of the tree and whenever you get to a leaf node you know you can insert that. You then can move up to the parent of that node you have just inserted and if it has no more children you can insert that. If it does have any any children you follow that down until you get a leaf then rinse and repeat.

Um... I hope I described that sufficiently.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Just thinking about it here is some pseudo code for the algorithm:

```
def insert_node(thenode):
    thechildren =  get_the_children_of_node(thenode)
    while len(thechildren) > 0:
        this_child = get_the_next_child
        insert_node(this_child)  # !!! recursive call !!!
        delete this_child
    insert thenode
```

This is a pretty simple algorithm if you use recursion. And it's very scalable.

I'm very sorry but I've had to give up on this. At the very least I've put it away for later.

issues.summary: Resample populations returning empty lists
issues.description:
When a population is clicked on in the resampling view for re-sampling populations many but not all populations return empty lists of plants to re-sample.

With help from Darryl this was diagnosed.
It was because the plant lists for resampling were never converted to using the elasticsearch data.
It is still using the original denormalised "PlantDataForSearch" table that must be rebuilt by the 
"run_denormalised_rebuilds()" stored function on the database.

So we will need to convert the resample view to use the elasticsearch data instead of this table.

issues.summary: Import error reporting for sample init needs more detail
issues.description:
When the spreadsheet to import provenance data is used while initialisin samples in the alternate provenances and there are problems with it.

The error reporting for each error does not say what column the problem is occurring on.
It's good that the line number is reported but we also need the column.
e.g.

```
Vineyard Block import errors:

    Line number: 1 '' value must be an integer.
    Line number: 2 '' value must be an integer.
    Line number: 3 '' value must be an integer. 
```

This makes it very difficult to figure out what is going wrong.

comments.body: This will need prioritisation too :-)
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Hi Zane, Yes I am looking into this because changes I made to fix #138 have
had implications with spreadsheet import.

On Tue, Feb 3, 2015 at 3:30 PM, Zane Gilmore notifications@github.com
wrote:

> This will need prioritisation too :-)
> 
> —

> >

I think that the column name is the absolute requirement.
Even if we didn't know exactly the problem at least we know which column.

I just spent about half an hour trying to track down which column was failing on the harvest_sample export.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
This can be considered a duplicate of #30.
However I have just noticed that this particular issue is for the Sample Init'

So perhaps we should just assume that this bug will not be closed until both imports are reporting the columns.

comments.body: Provisionally closing with the addition of column name where possible.

issues.summary: E-brida import not processing breeder names.
issues.description:
Uploading an e-brida file into the Kea/E-brida sample initiator failed for me, giving an error ending with this:
File "/home/keaapp/.virtualenvs/kea/src/kea/kea/ebrida/management/commands/ebrida_import.py", line 404, in create_samples
    plant, genotype, population = self.create_pedigree_data(data)
  File "/home/keaapp/.virtualenvs/kea/src/kea/kea/ebrida/management/commands/ebrida_import.py", line 527, in create_pedigree_data
    population = self.get_or_create_population(data)
  File "/home/keaapp/.virtualenvs/kea/src/kea/kea/ebrida/management/commands/ebrida_import.py", line 641, in get_or_create_population
    p.Breeder = self.get_breeder(data_row)
  File "/home/keaapp/.virtualenvs/kea/src/kea/kea/ebrida/management/commands/ebrida_import.py", line 550, in get_breeder
    breeder_name = data_row['BreederName']
KeyError: 'BreederName'

The spreadsheet's column header was: breederName
The breeder's name was: Canhong Cheng
, which exists in the database.

comments.body: Try changing the value in the column header from "breederName" to "BreederName" it will be case sensitive. That should allow you to import the spreadsheet.

Hey that does work! 

I did try fiddling around with spaces and capital letters and things, but I can't have had the right combination. Which is odd, because given the dictionary key this would be the obvious combination to try!

Thanks for your help.

issues.summary: Cannot find sample BAZ5937 from plate 1PS5

comments.body:
I think that this seems a bit confusing for me.

Could I please get a bit more detail?
Is this on the Live instance?

Because none of those entities seem to exist on the live instance.
One of them exists in the test instance.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
This is on the live instance, and was part of the 2014 Zespri sex testing
project.

There was a sample batch created for that project, SaB10RW. It included a
bunch of plates starting with 1PR- and 1PS-. We printed off the plate
sheets, and collected the samples.

Two of the plates in that sample batch were called 1PS5 and 1PS6. We have
the printed plate sheets in a folder here. The sheet for 1PS5 says it is
from the file 'Printer
Versionebrida_sample_batch_SaB10RW-20140912-151553.xls'. It contains
samples from 'BAZ5847' to 'BAZ5936'.

However, now when I log on to Kea and choose to look at samples and filter
the samples for that sample batch, doesn't show plates 1PS5 or 1PS6 - it
stops at 1PS4. Searching for sample 'BAZ5847' doesn't show any results, and
nor does filtering all samples for plate 1PS5.

However, when I instead choose to look at plates, plate 1PS5 does indeed
exist.

Mike

Hi Zane,

DELETE FROM "provenance_provenancedefintionfield" WHERE id=115;
ALTER TABLE "sauvignonblanc_vineyardblock" DROP COLUMN
"location_lat_long_id" CASCADE;

That cleaned up the sauvignonblanc_vineyardblock table for me. And in doing
so I see why the field was not deleted and I'll get it fixed: the admin
attempted to delete column 'location_lat_long', the actual column is
'location_lat_long_id'!

Regards,
Darryl

issues.summary: in Provenance data entry form dropdowns against large tables is silly
issues.description:
When a foreign key is defined for a provenance table the data entry form will just add a drop down to select from the foreign table.

When that table is huge (e.g. location) then the dropdown is so large that the page takes a while to download to the browser.

comments.body:
Currently this is a problem more with kea tables rather than dynamic tables.
Plan: Use the choose.widgets.ChooseWidgetWrapper in place of the standard SelectWidget on the relevant admin form. The ChooseWidgetWrapper select widget works with both kea and dynamic tables and with database and elasticsearch lookups.
Widget needs more work because of to_field values on dynamic tables.

comments.body: This seems to be working?

I am trying to upload a vineyard block spreadsheet without any "location_lat_long" values and it is insisting that this column is not null:
"IntegrityError: null value in column "location_lat_long_id" violates not-null constraint"
However this is the JSON in the defn for this column:

```
{
  "related_name":"block_location",
  "null":true,
  "to_field":"Name",
  "to":"pndata.Location",
  "blank":true,
  "unique":true
}
```

Not sure whether setting this to unique as well as setting it nullable is confusing things but it shouldn't.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Righto, I'll take another look.

Cheers,
Darryl
The original error seems to be OK though :-)
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
This may effect only foreign key columns that point to a kea table, a brief test of a dynamic table with foreign key to another dynamic table allowed a null value.

Plan: make a test, check the import_export widget used by KeaModelResource, check what is happening in the 'clean' method of the widget.

I'll have another look though by reimporting the db Zane previously sent me with the location fields because that is the only one that seems to fail?

Zane, please check your database, with the dump I have the column location_lat_long:

location_lat_long_id character varying(200) NOT NULL,

which clearly should fail. I changed that manually with:

ALTER TABLE sauvignonblanc_vineyardblock ALTER COLUMN location_lat_long_id DROP NOT NULL;

And then all good. I know the the definition field says allow null which may indicate 1. the table was initially incorrectly created or 2. the definition field was changed after creation and as we know the db table is not altered (the todo project). I don't think it was 1 because I can create fields with null:true and the table column is correctly created.

Upshot is that I am confident that this is no longer an issue - provided the database table column allows null.

issues.summary: Vintage drop down on harvest_sample data input page wrong
issues.description:
The dropdown created for the harvest_sample table for entering the Vintage is swapping the year number and the id field.
This means that the id is being displayed and the year number is the hidden value.

comments.body: fixed commit c857f31

issues.summary: Uploading plant_development or cultivation details only entered one row
issues.description: When I tried to enter in a whole bunch of plant_development rows or cultivation_details rows via the import excel mechanism, only one row was entered in.

comments.body: The source of the problem is that these models do not have a unique field to look up against so each row as parsed thinks that it is updating the object.

So we need to ensure that every provenance table has a unique identifier.
Or that we revisit the schema and ensure that the data is attached to the correct entities.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Looking at plant_development for example it seems to me that it needs 'unique_together = ('trial_plot', 'vintage').

But we have no way to edit directly the Meta of dynamic model.

​This was failing because these tables do not have a unique column that can be used by KeaModelResource to look up the row in the database - hence the discussion of LocalID that then can be used on any table that doesn't have an unique identifier.

The other more complex solution would be to create an admin resource to allow the editing of Meta attributes for dynamic tables (currently not implemented) so that thing like 'unique_together' can be used - this will be a major task in my opinion and not likely to be approved in the near future. (Probably best I don't mention it).
​Plan: ​Get LocalID working as unique identifier for dynamic tables without own identifier (#146)
autogenerated LocalIDField now available for tables without a unique identifier. The field accepts 'min-length' and 'prefix'.

issues.summary: Ensure LocalID column types are working correctly
issues.description:
While addressing #141 we discovered that a unique id will be required for some tables that might not otherwise need them.
So we need to ensure that the autoincrementing etc of LocalIDs work.

Which means being able to leave this column blank for new entries

comments.body:
Just checked this out on plant_development table where I have added a new localid column

When I uploaded a spreadsheet with that column empty it reported"

```
Line number: 1 development_LocalID This field cannot be null. 
```
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: ​I believe this will require a custom widget to be used by KeaModelResource. The file kea.provenance.resource already has some custom widgets and hooked up with the method KeaModelResouce.get_fields.

LocalIDField now available for tables without clear identifier.

This is a readonly field that auto-generates a local id. The field accepts 'min_length' and 'prefix':

{'min_length': 5, 'prefix': 'PFR'} produces localids like: PFR00001, PFR00002 etc

unique=True and null=False are natural attributes of this field.

However if the table has data then it might be a problem.

issues.summary: Proper checking of column headers in EBrida spreadsheets
issues.description:
I have just got an error report from an attempt to upload an EBrida spreadsheet.
The last lines of the traceback is:

```
File "/home/keaapp/.virtualenvs/kea/src/kea/kea/ebrida/management/commands/ebrida_import.py", line 626, in get_or_create_population
    if data_row['From Ped. Item'] in self.populations.keys():
KeyError: 'From Ped. Item'
```

It looked like the spreadsheet was missing a column that it needed to do the job.
So I hunted around trying to find where the checks were done to ensure that the spreadsheet complies with the minimum requirements for the upload.

And I can't find anywhere where this is happening.
"ebrida_import.parse_sheet" seems to be the sensible place to apply these checks but there is no sign of spreadsheet validation here. The spreadsheet sheet is read but it just dumps the contents into an array of dictionaries as is.

Presenting the user with an opaque error is not very useful so I think we need to capture this as the spreadsheets produced by EBrida are completely user defined and need to be defined absolutely correctly for our import.

comments.body: I think that this is done now
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Provenance migration handling
issues.description:
As provenances get complicated and take a long time to develop we will need to be able to develop them on a non-live instance then transfer the developed provenance to the live instance ready to be used.

Having to enter the new provenance by hand on the live instance just using the entries on the other instance is going to be fraught with problems and also very time consuming.

I thought perhaps just a way of dumping the inserts for the pertinent rows in the provenance definition tables then running the insert script against the live DB and restarting the live system.

comments.body: How about using django fixtures with dumpdata and loaddata commands?

Dumpdata in django 1.5 does not have the --pks option to restrict models to dump. So for example we can dump all provenance data with:

django dumpdata --indent 2 provenance

This dumps all provenance records, including the provenance users and all provenances with definitions etc and will therefore require a a good deal of manual editing to trim it down to the required rows.

The users can be excluded easily:

django dumpdata provenance --indent 2 --exclude provenance.provenanceuser

But still we have **all** provenance definitions dumped and manual edit will be required to get to the provenance we want to dump.

So, it seems to me that a management command will be required to dump a provenance, e.g.:

django dumpprovenance sauvignonblanc

I imagine that this will lever off the django dumpdata command, but will exclude pks, and collect the definition, fields, type and list objects required for the full provenance.

Then the matching command will be something like:

django loadprovenance sauvblanc.json

While I don't believe this to be a difficult task it will required some hours work to complete.

My thoughts and experiments.

What about later versions of Django?
You said Django 1.5 doesn't have the capability do later versions?

Would this simplify the process?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Yes, later versions would help the process. I still think that a custom management command will be the best solution (giving us more control) but later versions provide more options to the dumpdata command that can be levered for our custom command.

I also think we should use natural keys (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/topics/serialization/#topics-serialization-natural-keys) which are also available from Django 1.5.
Completed with b05b130 and others.

comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Hi Zane,

I've run through this myself and yes I'm finding some problems.
1. Dry run did not check uniqueness of latlong, but did display nice user error on 'complete' but without creating objects.
2. The 'to be created' user feedback is not working as expected and could well be confusing for the user.
3. After importing successfully (with latlong and all the rest) I was not able to use the import form to update rows - dryrun complained that objects already existed. That surprised me, we've tested that before - needs investigation.

But none of those are the errors you describe:

**1. 500 error when including latlong**: I've no idea, as stated I could excel import using 'Name' from pndata.Location objects. I received user feedback of errors on dryrun when attempting to import with non-unique latlongs in column. Note that location_lat_long field is 'unique' (check your forwarded spreadsheet where the column of latlongs is not unique).

**2. Spreadsheet should contain a Vineyardblock definition sheet**: Yes I understand this error, but provided the same title is used as for the downloaded skeleton spreadsheet - in this case "Vineyard Block" - then all is good on my instance. I don't understand why your instance should be requesting the title: Vineyardblock. Have definition names been changed on your instance?

**3. Column ordering on spreadsheets**: This can be changed by editing the order of the provenance definition fields of the provenance definition in the admin. But you know that. The "dump_provenance" command preserves the ordering, but as you have noted, if the ordering has not been changed then the 'order' field is the default value, 0. You can verify this in the sauvignonblanc_dump.json file. So the ordering of columns is arbitrary until ordered.

Hope that helps.

Darryl
Spreadsheet upload should now be working.

issues.summary: drop_provenance integrity error
issues.description:
Attempting to drop sauvblanc prov' on my dev instance gives:

```
IntegrityError: update or delete on table "django_content_type" violates foreign key constraint "contenttype_id_refs_id_140870f1" on table "provenance_provenancetype_provenance_definitions"
DETAIL:  Key (id)=(80) is still referenced from table "provenance_provenancetype_provenance_definitions".
```

comments.body:
Hi Zane,

Please check your sauvblanc provenance.

The script to discover the rows to be deleted relies on the ProvenanceList objects - this is an absolute requirement because this is the route by which the ProvenanceTypes to be deleted are discovered.

My guess is that at some point a ProvenanceType has been created that is no longer (or ever) referenced in a ProvenanceList.

Hope that helps,
Darryl
P.S. I was able to duplicate this error by creating an orphaned ProvenanceType.

Added more integral tables to drop_provenance command.

276021062447c9ba87c1fb711aa70a37f3912684
This hopefully could be closed, it does depend also on #163 which picks on the same tables and data.
Drop provenance appears to work now.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: provenance data dump
issues.description:
We need to explore creating a utility for dumping all of the data attached to a provenance.
The dump will need to be loadable onto an instance where the provenance exists.

The main anticipated issue will probably be dumping the likes of samples, sampleprocess, sampleextractprocess and processrun rows. There will be a few more too.
We will not be able to dump those entire tables but only those rows that are pertinent.

comments.body:
The drop_provenance management command seems now to be picking up all rows in all tables that are related to the data in the provenance's dynamic tables (these are all through the sample table).

Using this collection it should be relatively trivial to collect the data that needs to be dumped.
This is done now and also moot

issues.summary: Handling many-to-many field types in Provenance table
issues.description:
I have now added a many to many field into the Company table and the spreadsheet download (and I assume upload) seems to be excluding the many to many field.

I can certainly understand why as the table itself will actually contain the field.

I think we will be needing to construct a means of handling this relationship in a user-sensible way.

comments.body: There is a TODO comment in code for creating tables for manytomany relationships which is still to be done.

It should be noted that this work is for uploading data via the spreadsheets.
Both in the one table at a time Provenance admin upload and also the SampleBatch multitable/multisheet upload.
Also the data to be added into the spreadsheets should be definable a la the foreign key mechanism that is already used where the foreign entities are defined by a unique column on the foreign table which is defined by JSON on the provenance definition.

This may mean that the many to many table may have to contain the actual text-based (or whatever) data but... whatever works. The important thing is the user only needs to use things like LocalIDs or names to identify the foreign table row.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
I have just uploaded a new DB dump that contains a many to many between trial_plot and treatment.
There as also another one between company and contact.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Another thing that has just occurred to me is that many to many relationships are symmetrical.
It might be useful to be able to upload from both ends of the relationship, but if this looks too hard then we can just keep it from the direction that it was first defined like Django seems to like.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Hi Zane,

going to figure out how this is suppose to work. When I first worked on this I had troubles to come up with a bullet proof solution for m2m that none-computer savy persons could figure out. I believe I left it for later :/
Can you send me a sample spreadsheet that uses a m2m relation? That would help me figuring out how to parse the data and insert/update them in the DB tables.

Thanks
Stefan

This will need more doing then I was hoping for. Django's ORM does not support _to_field_ arguments for M2M fields. This will not work with the example spreadsheet since it refers to the _treatment.name_ field not the tables pk.

Not sure if a custom M2M field is the way to go or create a m2m through table. Latter will remove many ORM features and might cause big headaches with excel import/export. Not sure if a custom M2M field could take the _to_field_ parameter and take care to "translate" pk to the _to_field_ value. I can see big performance problems with that since it might cause a huge amount of SQLs.

Have to think about this!

Work is pushed to branch [issue-167].

Stefan,
My apologies.
There is a many-to-many column type that has been added and is working inside the admin interface.
This is why there are 2 tables that have been created in the sauvignonblanc provenance called:
sauvignonblanc_trial_plot_treatment
and sauvignonblanc_company_contact_person
These were created by the provenance definition mechanism and work fine (or well enough for now) in the admin interface.
What we will need is something that can process something like comma limited lists of the appropriate unique human readable names of the foreign table in a spreadsheet upload.
I realise that this is likely to be a non-trivial task.
I am thinking maybe that something that records both the human readable and id key of foreign table in the m2m? 

Perhaps we can talk tomorrow?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
The [issue-167] branch has my first try of this.
Created a new field _Many2ManyOnUniqueField_ (name up for change) that can take the _to_field_ parameter like FK fields. M2M values in spreadsheet are comma separated.
Because of the way Django ORM handles M2M values, they are missing in the excel import confirmation view but should work in the confirmed import.

Though I did not manage to create a spreadsheet that imports. All I got were integrity errors for ids to _sauvignonblanc_vineyardblock_. Hope I get behind that in two days.

Thanks for all that Stefan.
The field name is OK and not that important right now.
The to_field on that sounds like exactly what I want.

However I think that we will need to display the data in the upload confirmation. Otherwise user confusion will be rampant.

Thanks again, and please keep me posted,

issues.summary: Some tweaks for the upload confirmation of provenance data
issues.description:
I think we need to tweak the confirmation screen that is displayed immediately after uploading a spreadsheet for data input into a Provenance table:
- remove the crossed out "To be created" for when the entry is found and OK
- Change the "to be created" for a missing entry to "Missing!" highlighted in red
- Display the missing datum
- Show the spreadsheet line numbers

comments.body:
What you've done looks good but you still need to display the datum that couldn't be found.
(bullet point 3)
The displayed line numbers make it possible to easily see what I'm missing in the spreadsheet but for completeness and to make it as easy as possible for the user I still think you need to display what you couldn't find.

comments.body: And you also need to increment the reported row numbers by 1 to match the row numbers in the spreadsheet.

The bottom of the stack trace is the most worrying:
`UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xa0' in position 9: ordinal not in range(128)`

issues.summary: Assess Django upgrade to latest practical version
issues.description:
We need to assess how much work to migrate Kea to Django 1.x (min 1.7)

We need to be able to manage Provenance schema migrations using Django migrations.
Getting it going using South would be unwise as it is discontinued

comments.body:
Recommend upgrade to django 1.8 django 1.8 is LTS (long term support) which means it gets security updates for 3 years

See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/internals/release-process/#long-term-support-lts-releases

Also https://www.djangoproject.com/weblog/2015/apr/01/release-18-final/

Django 1.6

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/releases/1.6/
- Transactions
- disable autocommit for transactions
- enable transaction per request
- DiscoverRunner now bundled with django (can remove dependency on django-discover-runner)
- Update speed improvements (previously django runs select before update now just tries to update)
- foreign keys can now specify constraints https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/ref/models/fields/#django.db.models.ForeignKey.db_constraint
- ModelAdmin get_query_set renamed to get_queryset
- replace django-transaction-signals which is used for elasticsearch updates. Can most likely replace with another library or remove elasticsearch altogether as we discussed (https://django-transaction-hooks.readthedocs.org/en/latest/)

Django 1.7

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/releases/1.7/
- Remove south and replace with django migrations
- django.utils.importlib replace with importlib from python
- util modules renamed to utils

Django 1.8

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/releases/1.8/
- model meta api changed. May break elasticsearch relational lookup code and provenance perhaps?

This is the list that I've come up with. I suspect that the most likely things to break will be the elasticsearch and provenance stuff. I don't know how long  it will take to fix those if it does break because those are complicated parts of the system. At the very least we're probably looking at 2 - 3 days. Could be up to two weeks if things go horribly wrong. For this sort of upgrade I wish we had full test coverage.

The official OK has been given for this.
Matthew says that we should be running only supported stuff so we can defend the expenditure.

Thanks.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: I think that this is done now
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Trail -plot browse list and edit page not displaying the LocalIDs correctly
issues.description:
I have created this as a separate issue but I think that it may be associated with #167  as the Vineyard Block table is displaying its LocalID correctly.

In the Browse Trial_Plots page the Plot Identifier column is not being displayed according to the rules of the JSON in the ProvenanceDefinition field:

```
{
  "min_length":3,
  "prefix":"TP-",
  "unique":true
}
```

comments.body:
Not sure why that is but the LocalID field for trial plot is a character varying(50) in the DB not a bigint like the other LocalID fields (vineyard block ...).
Did you change that field at any time from character to LocalID type?
I tried to come up with a quick SQL but there are to many fk relations to that field from other tables. This might take some to figure untangle.

This is most likely caused by the provenance definition being changed at some point and the db tables not being updated to reflect it (seen such things before). This is exactly the problem we are trying to solve by upgrading to djago 1.8 and using migrations to handle schema changes to the dynamic provenance models. Will see what Zane has to say though.

You are dead right.
Thanks for that Stefan.

Will have a closer look at the tables to see if I can just fix it at the DB level.
Leave it for now. 
And thanks again for your time.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: This is done now I think
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: type "serial" does not exist: error on Provenance load
issues.description:
When the provenance is dumped then dropped and reloaded an error is generated:

```
FATAL ERROR - The following SQL query failed: ALTER TABLE "sauvignonblanc_harvest_sample" ALTER COLUMN "id" TYPE serial, ALTER COLUMN "id" SET NOT NULL, ALTER COLUMN "id" DROP DEFAULT;
The error was: type "serial" does not exist

DatabaseError: Problem installing fixture 'sauvignonblanc__provdump_20150619.json': Could not load provenance.ProvenanceDefinition(pk=15): type "serial" does not exist
```

comments.body:
The django 1.8 branch makes the fix for this redundant. The problem is how the provenance models are created automatically when the provenance definitions are imported when loading the json file using signal receivers and south. The django 1.8 branch solves this because it removes the signal receivers and handles migration of provenance models using django migrations.

Please let me know if you still want to fix this or would rather focus on 1.8 branch solution.

We need to check the dump and load of provenances on this Django 1.8 branch.
If it works then we have done this issue.

We also need to ensure that the fact that under this new 1.8 regime that we will have to do a syncdb after the load is documented somewhere. Perhaps that /docs/ thing?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: I had to make a few small alterations to the dump and drop provenance scripts. I've managed to drop and load back in the funny provenance. If you have any problems with it please let me know.
Forgot to add. After loading in a provenance with loaddata you need to run migrations with bin/django migrate.

comments.body:
I looked at Stefan's code. He has added a custom m2m field. I'm guessing here but I think his idea was to not use ManyToManyField but use his custom field for m2m relations instead. Did he mention anything to you about that?

Many2ManyOnUniqueField

The following fixes the problem. Error caused by required upgrade of django-import-export to work with django18 branch.

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/commit/c6cfb80e085c43e9ac6158b80cfc8dc9b09c416b

Need to update provenance definitions to use Many2ManyOnUnqiueField. See to_field is required to specify which field on the related model to use as lookup to parse values from spreadsheet.

{
 "related_name":"trial_plot_treatment",
 "to_field":"name",
 "null":true,
 "to":"sauvignonblanc.treatment",
 "blank":true
}

All m2m fields must be updated in all prov defs.
I think we can call this closed. I have had no problems recently with this.

issues.summary: Comma delimited list for provenance table upload seems space sensitive
issues.description:
It appears that if a space is inserted after the comma in the list of a M2M upload then that entry is ignored.
I was uploading this file:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4TupZPfpeyxZlkteXloOEllaDA/view?usp=sharing
into Company table.

After changing the the company contact to the "on unique field" M2M field type and adding the "to_field" to the JSON.

The upload work fine except that this problem occurred.
We need to ensure that white space on either side of the comma is trimmed and ignored.

comments.body:
The whitespace is already being trimmed.

"Damien  Yvon" isn't imported because the names don't match. See it has a double space in the name in the contacts table. Also Jeff Clark is spelt "Jeff Clarke".

There is no problem with the code. The problem is with the data.

Doh!
Thank you.
Although this demonstrates my personal dullness :-/
It also demonstrates a user interface bug, in that it silently ignores data.
I now think that we need to ensure that unfound entries in the m2m column are displayed on the confirmation screen in red and treated like any other unfound entries.

And perhaps we need to ensure that white-space is ignored in any searches.

issues.summary: Top level provenance schema structure needs tweaking
issues.description:
After trying to get the process handling going with the provenance system it has become apparent that we have not quite got things right for the structure of our schema.

The "Provenance" table is really the app within Kea that is created when we create a new Provenance.

This means that we should be making the "app_label" column on the "ProvenanceDefinition" table a foreign key to the "Provenance" table. Then we use the name column of the Provenance table as the app name.

This has become an issue when we apply a Provenance to a Sample container.
On a plate if there are samples that come from multiple specimen-types then we are in trouble.
The column in the SampleContainer table should not be ProvenanceTable but rather Provenance.

In the meantime, I am going to have to kludge it for the sample-containers in process handling but we do need to address this.

comments.body:
Notes on running migrations

Run migrations but skip the dynamic provenance models as these will not work until migrations are run.

SKIP_DYNAMIC_MODELS=yes bin/django migrate

Open psql or whichever GUI you like.

bin/django dbshell

provenance_id set to 1 initially. Need to fix manually. Look at all provenance definitiions and update the provenance_id fkey as required. The following worked for me. The last select is to check everything looks ok.

> select \* from provenance_provenancedefinition;
> update provenance_provenancedefinition set provenance_id = 3 where id not in (6, 7);
> select \* from provenance_provenancedefinition;

Required to run migrations a second time.

bin/django migate

issues.summary: Change the name of ProvenanceList to SpecimenType
issues.description:
I have been racking my brains for a better name for this table for months and I think that the name "SpecimenType" is a better name.

ProvenanceList is a stupid meaningless name that only causes confusion and needs to be changed ASAP.

It defines the list of tables, that samples are directly attached to, for a given Provenance (dynamic app).
These tables define the entities from which a sample is taken. The crop analog is the Plant table but for the provenance context there could be more than one entity from which samples will be taken.

After quizzing a few scientists around the place I have found that there is no generic word that means "entity from which a sample is taken". 
I had a flash of inspiration in the weekend and thought of the the word "specimen". It is not a direct match but it is close enough and, I think, manages to convey the meaning I want.
So in the spirit of computer (and other) scientists everywhere we are going to hijack the word specimen and redefine it as the "entity from which a sample is taken"... at least for within the Kea context.

comments.body: And so we dumped the "Type" off the end of that and just used "Specimen"
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Follow a population/samplebatch/tree/something...
issues.description:
Copy/paste from my email to Zane:

I was wondering it would be feasible to add support to Kea for a following/notification system, where a Kea user can choose to "follow" a sample batch (or population, or set of plates, or something...), and then get an email update when work is done on them.

This would be useful for example in Kiwifruit sex testing, where if we upload some sex testing results to Kea, a Kea user in Te Puke will receive a notification telling them their results are ready.

It may also be useful for a scientist who is working with a particular population to receive a notification when another scientist, working independently, screens their population with some marker - which they might otherwise never find out about.

One thing to note though. Your regex on line 78 looks wrong. I think it should be ^\d e.g. starts with a digit. Your regex is checking if there is a digit anywhere in the string.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Also I'll add that you can have the provenance model in the admin, just change the permissions so only superusers can edit if you like. I've copied this from the django admin docs.

ModelAdmin.has_add_permission(request)¶
Should return True if adding an object is permitted, False otherwise.

ModelAdmin.has_change_permission(request, obj=None)¶
Should return True if editing obj is permitted, False otherwise. If obj is None, should return True or False to indicate whether editing of objects of this type is permitted in general (e.g., False will be interpreted as meaning that the current user is not permitted to edit any object of this type).

ModelAdmin.has_delete_permission(request, obj=None)¶
Should return True if deleting obj is permitted, False otherwise. If obj is None, should return True or False to indicate whether deleting objects of this type is permitted in general (e.g., False will be interpreted as meaning that the current user is not permitted to delete any object of this type).

Something like this. Cannot add or delete via admin but edit is possible if superuser. Change to suit obviously. You can also define things like readonly fields etc to suit. Just a thought if you wanted to be able to change the provenance name or description via the admin.

``` python
class ProvenanceAdmin(admin.ModelAdmin):
    def has_add_permission(self, request):
        return False

    def has_change_permission(self, request, obj=None):
        if request.user.is_superuser:
            return True
        return False

    def has_delete_permission(self, request, obj=None):
        return False
```
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Thanks William,
That looks like a good idea for the Provenance admin.

As for the regex being wrong.
You will notice that I used match rather than search as I did for the other checks.
This does not make the regex explicit but it has the same effect.
( I have tested it)

issues.summary: Simple instructions on how to create and edit provenances
issues.description:
Our present set up for creating and editing provenances is starting to look pretty complicated.

What we need is a set of instructions to cover is to cover in a simple way:
- How to create a new provenance
- How to edit a provenance and cope with mistakes while editing.
- How to transfer a completed new provenance from one server to another.
- How to update a provenance schema using the migration mechanisms.

I think that a good place to put them is in the Sphinx doc server thingy.
Try to put them into a sensible place with an easy way to find them amongst whatever else is in there.

comments.body: Could you also ensure that you are aware of all of the tools that Darryl built for this sort of thing. e.g. provenance data dump. (which is currently broken #201 )

issues.summary: Get the doctests running
issues.description:
After the prov' def' changes in the DB schema that broke a lot of the doctests that Darryl wrote.
We need to get them going again.

comments.body:
The doctests are actually running now. See my commit here

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/commit/befd71ea8d7e37e883bd310024f9f77c554e63ef

Almost all of the tests are failing. Essentially testing provenances is problematic. Darryl was testing using the sauvblanc provenance. Any future changes you make to the sauvblanc provenance could essentially break the doctests because of the migrations stored on the filesystem and model definitions stored in the db. As it is anyway some of the doctests don't work because the tests are creating provenance models that do not have migrations on the filesystem.

Run the tests and see for yourself.

make doc-test
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
OK.
What I suggest is that we do not use the SauvBlanc provenance but use the Funny Provenance instead.
So we may need to create a funny provenance that has the required complexity to properly exercise the code but we will need to do this.
Testing against a proper provenance was probably a bad idea anyway but we could also just try to get the original sauvblanc prov and shoe-horn it into funny.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: Changing it to use a different provenance will be a lot of work. You would essentially be rewriting most of the tests from scratch. One solution with less effort would be to copy the sauvblanc provenance, give it a different prov name and app_label and use that instead. So you would end up with a sauvblanc prov for testing but the app_label/name would be something like sauvblanc_test
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
That was pretty much what I was suggesting.
However, for political reasons, I would prefer it if you not use any variant of sauvblanc or sauvignonblanc in the name of the provenance.

You will also have to deal with the new version of the provenance infrastructure table schemas.
i.e. specimen and the app_label foreign key in provenancedefinition.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
I spent most of yesterday playing around with this. There are a few really weird things going on.
1. Bug in postgres primary key sequences. Creating test objects fails because it's trying to create two objects in the same table with pkey of 1. No idea why. When I stuck a set_trace in it worked perfectly.
2. Tried to get around this by running each doctest in a transaction and rolling back to previous db state. This is the same way that the TestCase class in django works. this seemed to fix the postgres sequence bug. However now the doctests get about 2/3 through and hang. The test suite does not finish.

I have no idea what is going on here. Would like to have a chat to you about it today some time and perhaps get you to run the doctests to see if they hang for you.

Not sure how much time I have to spend on fixing these tests but at the moment it looks like 1 step forward and 3 back.
