issues.summary: Set up Travis CI for Kea
issues.description:
Travis has recently been made available for us at PFR and it has been suggested that we can use it for Kea.

So can we please put together a plan and and estimate for what we want to do and how to do it.

comments.body: Only problem I see here is that the integration tests run off a copy of the development database. So we would need to figure out a way around that.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
@wilbuick and @zanejg I have code that enable access to development database.

@zanejg you will be able to see [deploy-tools](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/deploy-tools).
comments.author: roy.storey

comments.body: The alternative is to have a test data set that gets initialised on Travis servers, but this ends up being too simple for true testing? This is currently the approach in [kakapo](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/kakapo)
comments.author: roy.storey

comments.body:
We could run the unit tests using a dataset that gets initialised on the travis servers. The integration tests are more problematic though because they depend on things like elasticsearch and essentially a copy of the development or production database.

The way the integration tests work at the moment is as follows.
- In development environment start to run the integration tests:

make integration-test
- This creates a new test database using the dev db as the template. Something like this:

CREATE DATABASE test_keadbdev TEMPLATE keadbdev;
- There is an optional step to populate the elasticsearch indexes too. From memory the ES indexes get prefixed with test_ during the test suite run. They are not deleted when the test suite completes because they do take a long time to populate with data.
- All integration tests are run against the test_keadbdev database.
- test suite complete, integration test db is dropped.

With a copy of the dev/prod db and elasticsearch indexes the size required on disk ends up being  somewhat large. Hopefully that won't be a problem. I know when I've used travis-ci in the past there was a 3 GB disk limit which I think would be a problem here.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
We need to see how much space we have to work with on the Travis server.
We're not sure how much space we'll need right now but it is likely to be non-trivial.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: E-brida information on harvest sheets
issues.description:
Sample harvests will be made a lot simpler if the Kea generated harvest sheets have the information that is on the actual trees/trays being harvested on them, instead of the kea codes, which are generally meaningless to the person harvesting.

So ideally platesheets for harvests created with the Initialise from E-brida function should have the tray name as well as the Kea ID, and then in each well should have the barcode or tree location. Is this doable? It would eliminate the need for a lot of cross-checking and the possiblity of human error. Chur'.

issues.summary: Initialise E-brida columns and formats
issues.description:
It seems that there can be a bit of variation in the spreadsheets output by E-brida for Kea upload. I'm not sure whose problem this is to fix, but I thought Kea should be aware - here are some examples I've come across:

The column 'synonyms' is sometimes called 'Synonym' or, once, 'BreederCrCode'.
The column 'BreederName' is sometimes called 'breederName'.
The column 'From Ped. Item' is sometimes called 'From Ped. Item (origin)'.
The format of the 'Start Date' column is now 'DD/MM/YYYY' (it used to be 'YYYY-MM DD').

The sheet to be read by Kea should be called 'Sheet1', but I've come across some with other names.

comments.body: Oh, I've just noticed there's already some discussion about this. Sorry.

issues.summary: Bug in E-brida initialisation?
issues.description:
Normally when we initialise samples from E-brida using the platetrays option, there are 94 samples from one population, or 46 samples from each of two populations, or 30 samples from each of three populations, so that adding two empty wells per population means there are 96 wells per plate tray.

We just tried to initialise some platetrays that had fewer than this number of samples, eg. 70 samples all from one population.

In theory Kea should know to start a new plate after this many samples by reading the 'Group' column in the E-brida spreadsheet, but it looks like it's ignoring this and continuing to fill the plate with the next samples.

I've just tried to attach the spreadsheets, but github is saying something went really wrong, and they can't process this file.

In related news, SaB10S9 should probably be deleted.

e.g.some thing like  @TabName:rownum
Which would look like @Cross:23

Don't care particularly about the exact syntax but we need something that works.
I believe that I did discuss this with Darryl at some point but I don't think that he implemented anything.

I imagine that this is not a trivial exercise but it will be required to get the last of the functionality going.

Could you please give me an estimate before you start if it looks too big.

issues.summary: Contact list not sorted for add new company
issues.description:
The add new company form has a list of contacts for the contact list.

It is not sorted correctly. It needs to be sorted alphabetically.
A better list box would be better too but not sure whether it's worth it the trouble.

So... we need to make sure that many to manys list-boxes are sorted.

comments.body:
I assume you're talking about the Company model in the sauvignonblanc provenance. In which case this is a dynamic model and you cannot apply generic sorting to all dynamic models because the fields will differ.

The way that django does this is by defining the Meta class as shown below

``` python

class Company(models.Model):

    """How to provide default sorting on a django model."""

    name = models.CharField()
    name2 = models.CharField()
    name3 = models.CharField()

    class Meta:
        ordering = ('name', '-name2',)

```

To provide the functionality that you want you would need a new field in the ProvenanceDefinition table that would contain a comma separated list of model fields for ordering. We could then take that value and place it into the model meta when the model class is created.

Are you happy with this solution?
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
That could work but avoiding changes to the basic DB schema is important right now.
What about another field for the json for each field?
Because that would be better.
Perhaps something along the lines of "ordering":n
Where n is an integer.
Where you look at each field for that field and order them relative to each other according to the relative number magnitude (negative for reverse order).
The lowest number being the first one to order by.

What do you think?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: I'm not sure exactly sure how that would work? Would need to discuss that with you
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body: Actually I do know what you mean after I read that twice. I like my approach better to be honest. My solution does require migrations but doesn't change the model schema at all. You're better off doing things the django way, you will end up with less problems in the long run.

issues.summary: Order column numbers are being changed every time the table is viewed in editor
issues.description:
Not sure exactly how this is happening but every time that I go to a table in the provenance definition editor the numbers in the order column all seem to have 1000 added to them.

What really bothered me was that one table seemed to only add a thousand to 2 of the columns in the table.

Also, and very disturbingly, whenever I did a refresh on the editor the numbers in the order column incremented by 1000.

comments.body:
It's a dirty hack by me to get around problems with form validation.

Basically it works like this

Current order of prov def fields

1,2,3,4

you set the new order of the prov def fields to to change field order.

2,3,4,1

Django complains because 1,2,3,4 are already being used. This means form validation fails and you cannot save the form ever. If you want to save the form you need to do it in two steps
1. change order from 1,2,3,4 to 20,40,30,10 for example
2. Change from 20,40,30,10 back into 2,4,3,1

That is essentially what the hack of adding 1000 does. Because remember there is a unique constraint on the order column.

Where my little hack falls over is when you save the form and the form validation fails. When this happens the fields in the order column get incremented by 1000. This is because I need to increment the fields in the order table by 1000 before validating the form and when form validation fails the order is already saved. We could potentially subtract 1000 from the order and resave when the form fails it's validation. That might fix the problem.
comments.author: will.buick

We want to explore the possibility of pulling the use of Elastic Search for populating the datagrid widgets.

I think that there are 2 other ways of populating the datagrid widget one uses the ORM and the other uses raw SQL.

We will need to explore both possibilities for different datagrids. Presumably dependent on the complexity of the query being presented.

So, to start with I have suggested replacing the View Sample grid for the alt provenances and checking that out on a branch to assess its speed etc.

Marek has also suggested that we make it a settings file entry to be able to switch where the datagrid gets its data from, but each data source will need to be defined.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Changing the populations datagrid turned out to be pretty easy in the end. There was already a populations datagrid view that Darryl added in  that ran off raw sql. This was in the file populations/views/resample_search.py. I ended up copying over the code and it seems to work.

Things to be aware of.
- Powering the datagrid from rawsql is making use of postgres stored functions.
- Getting a list of csv separated altnames requires using postgres stored function
- Getting localid requires postgres stored function.

Have a look and then we can discuss.

A line that is in green if all is well and if any errors are found then the line needs to be in red stating the nature of the error and at what line.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Hi Zane,

I have done some research into this and we should probably discuss what I've found.

The library that darryl is using (django-import-export) does not provide  any sort of validation that I am aware of. Instead it accepts everything and lets django models/database handle the validation which is why you get those lovely exception tracebacks.

For example, how the code handles integer fields
1. Try convert the value to an integer
2. If cannot convert return None

It is essentially ignoring errors. The only custom validation that we have there that I can see is the "Missing!" handler. This doesn't actually validate anything or prevent you from importing the data.

So, if you want validation without showing those exception tracebacks I think we would be looking at a custom solution built on top of the django-import-export library. That is unfortunately not a 5 minute job.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
OK let's have a good discussion about this.
It would be nice to have at least a vague notion of how long it would take (i.e. how much moola) to do all of this.

comments.body:
this is still extant and needs to be addressed 
I think

comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Have found the problem. The problem is that a table has a foreign key to the pndata.Location table. This table is not a provenance table and causes the whole system to crash.

The provenance admin page (http://localhost:8000/provenance/admin/) shows a list of all of the tables in the provenance. The integrity tree code is what does this. This also follows any foreign keys that a provenance definition has. This is what detects the pndata.Location table and adds it to the list of models on the provenance admin page.

The NoReverseMatch exception is raised because the pndata.Location table is not registered in the django admin. The provenance admin page tries to include a link to the Location admin add page (which does not exist because the model is not registered in the admin).

I did check the pndata/admin.py file and discovered that the LocationAdmin was originally registered in the admin but is now commented out. I am not sure of the reason for this so you will need to let me know.

I did try enable the LocationAdmin class and the page did load but that uncovered more errors because the provenance admin page is not designed to handle non provenance models. The error was that the link to browse all records in the table did not work (datagrid). This is caused by the pndata.Location model is not a provenance model.

Would like to get your thoughts on the best way to solve this problem.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
I think that something that just skips any tables that are not in the provenance for the integrity tree would be in order.

I don't understand why the integrity tree is being used in that code. I thought it was only for figuring out the order of inserts in the batch upload file.

issues.summary: Ebrida initialisation: Populations and Groups.
issues.description:
Kea's Initialise Ebrida function was originally added for Kiwifruit sex testing. The Populations in the Ebrida generated spreadsheets had 'nice' numbers of plants (eg. 30, or 46, or 94, or 188), so that populations filled up plates nicely. The Groups column had 'nice' numbers too: 3x30, or 2x46, or 1x94, (populations x samples) so that each Group - meaning one Tray - corresponded to a full Kea plate. This worked nicely (or did, until the Ebrida spreadsheet formats all changed...). Things do not work so nicely when the numbers are not so 'nice'...

One example is in my issue #209 - Groups don't correspond to Plates when there are fewer than one population of 94 samples, or 2 populations of 46 samples, or 3 populations of 30 samples in a Group. Paradoxically, Mareike received an Ebrida spreadsheet where the entries in the Group column were the orchard position of the plant, and therefore every entry was unique. Initialising plates in Kea meant that each sample was put into its own plate. Although this was a while after I posted #209 and something may have changed since then?

For some harvests, there are only one or two samples from each population. Unchecking 'Leave two blank wells between populations' removes the two blank wells from the start of each plate, too. These two blank wells at the start of each plate should always be there.

Kea imposes a limit of _94 plants per Group_, even when there are no plates being collected (only bags or tubes), and even when no blank wells are to be left. The error message for exceeding this limit says there is a limit of _96 plants per Group_.

These issues are quite important: combined with the non-uniformity of the Ebrida spreadsheets themselves (column titles changing; Pedigree Item sometimes being Orchard Position and sometimes K14.018.001 or whatever; different date formats...), they mean that sometimes up to ten trial runs are needed on keatest to make sure things are going to work as expected. They have resulted in the creation of more than one rubbish Sample Batch, and there is still an Ebrida Sample Batch from October that I have been unable to create in Kea.

comments.body: Marek, we will need to spend some time on the EBrida import issues like this next year.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Mike,
I have done some work on all of this.
Perhaps these issues have been addressed?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Cool! I'll leave a report if I find any problems.

You may have fixed this in your most recent update, but I just noticed that in that big Ebrida spreadsheet I sent you (Trays 108-224 or something), if you look at tray 223 it should be half full, and tray 224 should be full. The Kea platesheets I initialised a week or two ago from this spreadsheet puts the first half of the tray 224 samples into tray 223, and the second half of the tray 224 samples into the first half of tray 224. In other words, it did what my paragraph two in the opening comment described. Did it work correctly when you tested this spreadsheet?
This seems to be fixed now

issues.summary: Initiate Samples from EBrida
issues.description:
Priority: High

Researchers export an excel sheet from ebrida to niotiate KEA samples. The column headiers do not exactly m,atch which drives them nuts:

Examples:
- The meaning of the header Group differs between KEA and EBRida. EBRida exports the location on the field as a group. but KEA interprets that as a sample layout. A side remark: The sample layout is in KEA restricted to 96 samples, but they have now boxes with 100 sample!
- No start date in the ebrida excel export
- ebrida headers have lower case characters in the headers where KEA uses upper case letters
- Tree barcode does not get imported
- Plant location should not be imported to plan alt name it should be a separate field

comments.body:
I think we need to figure this out between everybody that uses this import functionality.
It looks like the potato people will be using it soon too.

I put together things like the group column to be used for plate layout because that is what some people asked for.

To be able to handle other plate or multi-sample containers comprehensively we need to do some fairly significant work.

The translation of fields from EBrida to KEa certainly does need some work but be need to be sure we get it as right as we can so I suggest we get together everybody who has a stake and everybody who has the required knowledge and nut it out.

comments.body: This has been done.

The datagrid sorting and searching very very slow.
So we will have to make some modifications for it to work satisfactorily.

We have decided that adding a LocalID_str column to the plant table that is automatically populated should solve this. Then we can index on it and get things humming along nice and fast.
The same things also apply for #263.

To start with we will add the columns in the models.py file for pndata.
Then we populate the columns:
- Plants: `update pndata_plant set "LocalID_str" = getplantlocalid(id);`   This took approx 45 minutes on my dev' machine.
- Genotypes: `update pndata_genotype set "LocalID_str" = getgenotypelocalid(id);` And this took about an hour!

issues.summary: Kea Form:And another test
issues.description:
Posted by Zane Gilmore (zane) on the Issue Form in Kea

---

Elephants are large mammals of the family Elephantidae and the order Proboscidea. Two species are traditionally recognised, the African elephant (Loxodonta africana) and the Asian elephant (Elephas maximus), although some evidence suggests that African bush elephants and African forest elephants are separate species (L. africana and L. cyclotis respectively). Elephants are scattered throughout sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, and Southeast Asia. Elephantidae is the only surviving family of the order Proboscidea; other, now extinct, members of the order include deinotheres, gomphotheres, mammoths, and mastodons. Male African elephants are the largest extant terrestrial animals and can reach a height of 4 m (13 ft) and weigh 7,000 kg (15,000 lb). All elephants have several distinctive features the most notable of which is a long trunk or proboscis, used for many purposes, particularly breathing, lifting water and grasping objects.

issues.summary: DNA Alternative Provenance Requirements
issues.description:
# Draft Notes on an Alternative Provenance for Kiwifruit DNA Samples
## GOAL

> to be able to assign a unique ID and track usage of **historical** DNA (or RNA) samples that have not been collected though a KEA best practice process
### What we want to remember
- old location (lab, location)
- person providing
- local identifier
- putative eBrida PI the sample is _believed_ to have come from
- other metadata about sample
  - extraction method
  - concentration or other QC

issues.summary: Build usable security model for Kea API
issues.description:
After some discussion we have decided to use a token based security model for Kea.
Where the user will go to a page on Kea and produce the "magic number" which can be copied and used for authentication by an API client.

Some work to ensure that the present API endpoints are properly making use of this mechanism is also required.

comments.body: I've committed the changes to this into a branch called api_token. The reason for this is I've recently switched over to debian (then ubuntu a week later... broken graphics drivers...) on my laptop and in order to easily do so I've needed to make my development environments more portable hence the switch to developing with docker. The advantage of this is that it takes minutes rather than hours to build myself a development environment from scratch. This change meant rather considerable changes to the repository structure so I branched it. This branch has vagrant stripped out replaced with docker and removed buildout to replace with pip. Feel free to take whatever you want from this branch but the pertinent code for this issue can be found in the commit referenced above.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:

I hope you have tried to reduce the complexity :-)

Do you think that this might be applicable to the production instances?
i.e. test and live.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

I'll need to integrate that with what I've done. You should be able to test the api but the new changes that you've made to the api won't be available until I've merged the code properly.

comments.body:
I have taken into account the following api notes

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/wiki/API-Notes

The following endpoints are done
- samples
- sample containers
- crops
- species
- populations
- plants
- genotypes
- locations
- location types
- processes - read only endpoint currently.
- provenances
- provenance specimens
- all dynamic provenance models
- sample batch initialisation for crops

The sample batch initialisation will need to be discussed to determine the best way to implement it and the provenance batch initialisation requires some thought because it's a multi step process which is more problematic to implement using an api.

@zanejg can you explain more specifically how the `__str__` method will be used in this context?
i.e. why did you choose to format these specific attributes in `grape_and_wine.Trialplot`?:

```
__str__(self):
        return "{0} Field#{1} Trial:{2}".format(self.plot_identifier,
                                                self.trial_plot_number,
                                                self.trial)

issues.summary: POST Samples,plants gentoypes and populations API endpoint needs to create new localids
issues.description:
When I try to post a new sample using the API, it returns an error complaining that it needs the localid.

I am assuming that this also happens with plants and genotypes and populations.

These should not have the localids sent via the API. The localids should be left null and they should be generated. We should also send back the newly created localids as a return value.

comments.body:
API changes are now in the branch found here

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/tree/api_write_access

Populations, Genotypes and Plants now all set LocalID's correctly.

These endpoints now also correctly restrict related (foreign key) querysets to the crop context provided in the url. These three endpoints should be safe to now provide write access. 

Zane should review these endpoints to check if any further validation checks are required when creating records.

The sample and sample container endpoints are now read only. We may allow these endpoints to update (but not create). Further discussion is required to decide what fields should be editable in this case and what extra validation checks are required.

The current thinking is that creating samples and sample containers will be restricted to sample batch initialization only.

The provenance model endpoint is an automatically generated endpoint based on the model schema. As such it is not possible to have extra validation checks. If this becomes necessary then further work would be required to allow for this functionality.

Take this provenance model endpoint as an example cereal_breeding.CerealPlant

http://localhost:8000/api/provenance/5/model/213/

This endpoint allows posting data for the plant_localid field. Assuming that the localid fields should not be editable via the api the model schema would need to be changed to set editable=False (same as pndata local ids) on all localid fields.

All provenance models should be tested through this endpoint to ensure that the api behaves as expected.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body: Assuming we did this
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Move samples process only applying the last location to all samples
issues.description:
When different locations are entered for samples in the move sample process only the first location is applied to all of them.

This is potentially disastrous.

comments.body:
Note to self:
Look at processExcel.py lines 1880-1896
This is might be where the problem resides.

Also look at moveSampleFromProcRun function at line 2863
particularly in the else clause on line 2938

comments.body:
After looking at this in more detail I believe I had it wrong.
Things were happening correctly.
The samples that were getting the same location were all on plates.
So the location was being applied to the plate, which is correct.

issues.summary: Need to Have Multipopulation Plate Layouts Sorted as Block Layout
issues.description:
re enhancements in https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/commit/285bd5a8fa9f9bface615839c58eaf6dcb531000

Following discussions with @mareikek ..
Square sheet formats with "Populations as column"  option look good but we need plate layout to mirror sheet layout 

i.e. Samples ordering should be in order
1. Block
2. Row
3. Bay
4. Position

regardless of populations

comments.body: Also please display barcode/location in plate layout sheet!

I am thinking that perhaps some sort of report is in order. This means we can have a bit more flexibility.  What will definitely be required is for the locations to be put in before the spreadsheet is produced
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Hi gang,
Just to clarify, there are three issues here:
1/ The trees are labelled with what Kea calls AltNames and not with Kea LocalIDs. Therefore, the platesheets or sample lists should contain these in addition to or instead of Kea LocalIDs so we know what we're meant to be collecting.
2/ The sample information should be sorted in the order the plants appear in the field so that the collectors don't have to walk back and forwards up the same rows. This will drastically decrease the time required for the harvests.
3/ The samples should be collected in the order they will go into the plates. That is, we can't just leave the assigned plates and wells as they are and order the collection sheets by tree location because although this will deal with the previous problem, it will mean that for example the first sample should be collected into Plate 1, well D6; the second into Plate 3, well E9; etc., which increases the chance of error. Therefore the samples should be ordered by orchard position and then assigned plates and wells in that order.
The orchard positions look like "TP14.34-17-06c".
TP - Te Puke site
14 - I think this means planted in 2014, so it can be ignored.
34 - block 34
17 - row 17
06 - bay 6
c - the third plant in bay 6
There are typically about six trees in each bay, but I've seen it go up to i.
Please point out where I've misunderstood.

Exact same issues with initialise eBrida

Sent from my iPhone

On 9/09/2016, at 5:16 PM, mcvmcv <notifications@github.com<mailto:notifications@github.com>> wrote:

1/ The trees are labelled with what Kea calls AltNames and not with Kea LocalIDs. Therefore, the platesheets or sample lists should contain these in addition to or instead of Kea LocalIDs so we know what we're meant to be collecting.
2/ The sample information should be sorted in the order the plants appear in the field so that the collectors don't have to walk back and forwards up the same rows. This will drastically decrease the time required for the harvests.
3/ The samples should be collected in the order they will go into the plates. That is, we can't just leave the assigned plates and wells as they are and order the collection sheets by tree location because although this will deal with the previous problem, it will mean that for example the first sample should be collected into Plate 1, well D6; the second into Plate 3, well E9; etc., which increases the chance of error. Therefore the samples should be ordered by orchard position and then assigned plates and wells in that order.
The orchard positions look like "TP14.34-17-06c".

14 - I think this means planted in 2014, so it can be ignored.
34 - block 34

06 - bay 6

There are typically about six trees in each bay, but I've seen it go up to i.
Please point out where I've misunderstood.

issues.summary: Non normalised data in grape_and_wine
issues.description:
Data is poorly normalised for grape and wine.
This is most obvious between the Bunch, Vine and TrialPlot entities:
- A Bunch can come from a TrialPlot and/or a Vine
- A Vine can have no TrialPlot or one that differs from its child Bunch
- Both Vine and TrialPlot can have vineyard_row and bay_of_row (even if the Vine comes from a TrialPlot with differing row and bay)

These issues mainly stem from TrialPlot being a specimen table which is necessary for sampling methods in which single vines are not identified

comments.body:
For now, I think we can ignore bunch.
The Vine TrialPlot thing I think we can live with for now.
The row and bay for the specimen, we can assume are the ones that will take precedence.
If this becomes a problem we can address it but right now let's not make more work for ourselves.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: Sounds good. I think the root issue is #348 and once we have started doing that the solution will be clearer.
comments.author: tim.millar

issues.summary: Kea INIT sheet layout for orchard locations
issues.description:
Currently the location details are in order

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/268441/17953999/16d6883e-6acc-11e6-970d-f91ae5615800.png)

they  should be in Block Row Bay VineID order

comments.body: See #331. A report will get this done quickly.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
After a long discussion with John I have finally worked out what is required here and it will take some development work from William and Hymmi to get done.

Hymmi's Shiny app that produces the spreadsheets for the EBrida Initialisation will need to have an extra column added to it called Plot Location.

The EBrida-file code in Kea to parse the upload file will need to be able to parse the locations as they are.
So we will need to asses whether the location conforms to the standard and if it doesn't then ignore it with an error.
Then we will need to search for the pertinent location and if it does not exist then add it.
Then the list of plants being listed in the spreadsheet will need to be sorted according to:
1. block
2. row
3. bay
4. vine

The list of plants in the data tab can then be in that order and the plate sequence can be added as before.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
This is an example of one of the locations we might expect.
**T03.32-05-17c**
- **T03.** The first 4 chars say the site and year of creation. In this case it means T for Te Puke and 2003. For our purposes we can ignore the year. The sites are T for Te Puke ( I think K for Kerikeri and M for Motueka but that needs confirmation)
- **32** Denotes block number
- **05** Is row number
- **17** Is bay number
- **c** Is the Vine id

John could you please confirm this?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: added Plot Location column to the csv from the app @ [9196c9c](https://github.com/hymmikong/eBrida/commit/9196c9cfdf7d2ba2a2cd80a7e951ee5c0d2c40b4) :+1:
comments.author: hymmi.kong

comments.body: as discussed today @jasi1986 ...lets check this out with red parent collections

[Luis_Males4MarkerTesting_JS.xlsx](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/files/471415/Luis_Males4MarkerTesting_JS.xlsx)

is an example of collection planned by @jasi1986 and @luisgea for testing, exported from eBrida

I've just tried this spreadsheet in keatest. There are a couple of problems:
1/ There's a second sheet with some other information. Solved by deleting the second sheet.
2/ The tree location is in the 'group' column, which Kea understands as the plate name, so each sample is harvested into its own plate.
3/ There are a lot of different populations on the two plates. In this situation, we would want the option to not leave two empty wells between each population, but still have two empty wells at the start of each plate. The checkbox for empty wells does sets them both.

Also, the 'From Ped. Item' column is a copy of the 'Pedigree Item' column - normally if the Pedigree Item is 'K10.0031.00586', the 'From Ped. Item' column will be 'K10.0031', which I think becomes a Kea Population AltName. So by importing this sheet, we end up with each plant in it's own population, despite what the 'breederCrCode' column says, or what the 'From Ped. Item' column would usually say.

Ok so I just tried the following with the above file:
1. Pasted the pedigree items into the app at http://shiny-dev.powerplant.pfr.co.nz/LookupLoc-eg/
2. Selected **create kea init**  in single sample mode and exported the csv file which I saved  as 

[LuisMaleskeainit.xlsx](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/files/473544/LuisMaleskeainit.xlsx)
3. Uploaded this to **Initialise eBrida**
4. Downloaded the file 
[ebrida_sample_batch_SaB10VS-20160915-100433.xlsx](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/files/473547/ebrida_sample_batch_SaB10VS-20160915-100433.xlsx)

So as far as I can see the issues are:
1. Kea is assigning each genotype to its own population as @mcvmcv has noted. 
2. The barcodes need to be accompanied by locations i.e. 'Group' in eBrida speak
3. ...and the genotypes could then be sorted in data sheet by Block/Row/Bay/Position whether in single or plate collections and 
4. The plate ordering needs to be sorted in the same way
I have updated the app to get the CrossName in the 'From Ped. Item' column. Hopefully will solve the individual population issue

issues.summary: Contact person m2m choice field in Company admin form not sorted
issues.description:
M2M fields will need to be sorted.
If there is any kind of decent number to choose from it is awful to find them without sorting.

comments.body:
There are two ways to solve this problem and examples of both have been included in the commit.

The first is to set the default ordering of a model using the model Meta. An example of this is shown here. This option would need to be set per model as required.

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/commit/d5963aa97dbc5f6732a96c0fc8d54bca79155586#diff-667531a35968de880a4bb78b757ce449R52

The second approach was to make all m2m fields use the datagrid select mechanism in the admin. The code for this can be seen here

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/commit/d5963aa97dbc5f6732a96c0fc8d54bca79155586#diff-cbb7a1134e0bc33f63e1cafa2b3dbe6dR137

The correct approach is most likely a combination of these two. The datagrid select solves the clunky multi select widget and the default ordering sets the ordering of the model anywhere it is used that doesn't explicitly set it's own order.

issues.description:
Create a provenance for Kiwifruit microbiome work.
Working with Sarah Thompson.

Started schema design in dia on branch [f/kiwifruit_microbiome_provenance](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/tree/f/kiwifruit_microbiome_provenance)

comments.body:
Details to discuss with Sarah:
- both vines and orchard_block have a rootstock option. I guess this is for flexibility but it is ideal if this information is only stored in one place (maybe in trial_plot?)
- I reversed one-to-many relationships from cultivation_details because that makes more sense? I.e many orchard_blocks or trial_plots can have the same cultivation details.
- There are several date specific fields in cultivation_details that make me think it should only connect to trial_plot as I imagine that orchard_blocks are more of a permanent entity.
- Irrigation type is something that may change over time so it may be best to added it to cultivation_details instead of orchard_block.
- several foreign keys that we're uncertain about marked in red in schema diagram

issues.summary: Firefox updates break Selenium tests
issues.description:
To run Firefox, the Python Selenium library needs to have been released at around the same time. If we let Firefox stay current, we have to keep Selenium current too.

How do we want to handle this? Hold back Firefox, keep updating Selenium, or something else (like using a different browser)?

comments.body: My local solution was to use Firefox ESR (Extended Support Release). That means I can keep using older Selenium versions for longer. Just another option to consider.

issues.summary: Dates in provenance downloads are not compatible with the uploads.
issues.description:
Because of the way that updates to Kea provenance data is done we need to ensure that the dates that are downloaded via the Datagrid "Export to Excel" for the provenance data is able to be uploaded via the "Excel Import"

Right now the Datagrid data dump is converting the dates to a string a la YYYY-MM-dd.
And the upload is not able to parse it to a date. 

So we either have to make the upload able to parse it or make the download produce a date.
If I have to choose then the former is preferable, although both might be better as it is better to have the upload as flexible as possible and the download should try to preserve the data in a state that honours the original as perfectly as possible.

comments.body:
I couldn't replicate the datagrid dumping the date as YYYY-MM-dd. Perhaps this is related to a particular field/model. Perhaps you could point me at the particular datagrid that is causing the problem.

In regards to parsing of dates from excel import you should be able to configure the accepted formats by setting the DATE_INPUT_FORMATS and DATETIME_INPUT_FORMATS. Django provides default values for these but they can be added to the base settings file and customized. django-import-export which does the excel parsing uses those settings to parse the date.

I can discuss this further with you next week if you like.
comments.author: will.buick

issues.summary: A more efficient method for initialising samples
issues.description:
Hi Kea dudes,

So I've just been initialising some samples for our annual(ish) apple harvest. This year it consists of two multi-population batches, each consisting of 20ish populations.

The data I receive in order to do this is a spreadsheet that looks something like:
`Population | Mother               | Father               | Number`
`AA0208      | A001R001T001 | A001R001T002 |        257`
`AA0209     | A001R001T001 | A001R001T003 |        117`
`...`

with one row per population, and one spreadsheet per sample batch. The Population column is to be a population altName; the Mother and Father columns are altNames of plants that may or may not exist in Kea, and may or may not have isParent = True; and the Number column is the number of plants in that population.

Currently to initialise these, I need to:
Make a new list of unique parent altNames
Search Kea for plants by each altName, and check if each one exists
If a plant exists, check that it is isParents=TRUE
If it does not exist, create a genotype via the admin screen and add the altName, then create the plant via the admin screen and add the altName
Using the admin screen, create each population, each time searching the sample table for the parents and setting them as the parents, adding the population altNames; selecting the same Breeder and cross date every time.
Create the multi-population batch, selecting my new populations
Make sure the generated spreadsheet lists them in the right order, and enter the number of plants for each population

Today this has taken me over two hours so far. It strikes me that if I could just upload the above spreadsheet, and gave a bit of additional info like Breeder and Cross Date or whatever, the parents could be get_or_created or something, and isParent=TRUEed; and the populations created and given altNames; and the correct number of samples added automatically. And it would take about four seconds.

So my questions are:
1. Is there currently a much quicker way to achieve all of this? (i.e. am I a moron?)
2. Can I try to outsmart Kea somehow (probably not...) I mean can I manipulate this spreadsheet somehow to create a list of all the samples, and tell Kea it's an Ebrida spreadsheet and initialise it that way or something? (I'm guessing no, because the plants don't have Barcodes/LotIDs/PlotIDs/Locations/Social Security Numbers/EbridaPedigreeItems or whatever).
3. Can something be added to Kea so that it understands this sort of spreadsheet?

Thanks,
Mike

comments.body:
Also,
4. I can't seem to add labels to my issues.
I think we have done this with the eBrida upload stuff
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Location type for cryopreservation
issues.description:
As part of the potato project, they are looking to use cryopreservation.

Ranjiths description:

> I have attached the sheet we have developed so far. We are not taking any risk of loss. So, when we receive a potato variety in a tissue culture tub or as microtubers from Lincoln, we first multiply into 3 -4 tubs to get about 30-40  plantlets. For cryopreservation, we use 120 buds (both shoot tips and developed axillary buds). They go into: 4 cryo tubes each having 25 buds and another fifth with 20 buds. So we have 5 tubes in liquid nitrogen. One with 20 buds comes out after a week or so and get tested for viability and if we have >40  % viability, that variety is in permanent storage in 4 tubes.
 In the Dewar we have chambers A, B, C, D and within the chambers we have towers A-1, A2 … D1, D2 etc. Each tower has 12 positions which can take one cryo box each. Cryo boxes have their barcodes (box bar code  in sheet), can take 48 cryo tubes with barcode (tube barcode in sheet). For each cultivar we allocate two towers taking two tubes each. We have now placed 2 tubes per variety of 18 varieties in their final resting place. The other two tubes will be placed in another tower from their temporary storage position and the sheet will be updated. We also write down the position of each tube within the box.
So, for Kea, we can only identify the tube (not the individual 25 shoot tips in it) and link it to the variety. A variety will have four tubes in four different positions, using two boxes that are in two different towers.

In this case the material being stored is a viable plant (a specimen) so I think this should be modeled in the locations table (could also contain samples/sample-extracts). Obviously we cant track the individual plantlets in each tube but each tube could be treated as a single specimen (or other entity).

comments.body:
Potential implementation:

* Create a location type "Dewar position" with coordinates for "Dewar", "Chamber" and "Tower".
* Create a container type "Dewar Tube" that can store the projects barcode associated with each tube
* Add "Container" as an option to the Specimen table of the provenance 

@zanejg the only issue with this is that specimens already require a location. if they are in a container that also requires a location then we are duplicating information.
comments.author: tim.millar

comments.body:
Simpler plan:

* Create a location type "Dewar position" with coordinates for "Dewar", "Chamber" and "Tower".
* Add "Plant type" column to potato specimen table
  * foreign key to table of plant types
  * not nullable 
* Add "Cryostorage barcode" column to potato specimen table
  * unique
  * nullable

issues.summary: Nested containers and locations
issues.description:
Currently Kea has several different ways of answering "where is this thing located".
For Specimens this is just a foreign key to the locations table.
Locations themselves can be nested.
Samples and sample extracts have a container and the container itself has location (which may be nested).

This is working for the most part but there are a couple of limitations:
 * Containers are often nested e.g. a bar-coded tube inside a  bar-coded box at a location.
 * Specimens (plants) can often have a container instead of just a location e.g. a plant in a numbered pot that is moved between greenhouses or a plantlet in an agar plate in a fridge in a lab

I think there is a way to represent this relationships without too much change to the current system:

We could add new "pseudo" locations to the locations table that point at a container in the container table. This is a (tree-like) recursive relationship between containers a locations. A container must have a location which could be a 'real' location or another container-location.
This would effectively be treating containers as a type of location that can be moved (taking its contents with it).

Pros:
 * More flexible model of the (fundamentally nested) nature of containers/locations
 * From the users point of view, there is a single (compulsory) option that states where a 'thing' is located
 * Existing Specimen's locations are unaffected as there is still a foreign key to location table
 * New specimens can have a container via the location table
 * Samples and Sample-extracts can still be forced to have a container (foreign key to container table) and are unaffected 

Cons:
 * Potential for deeply nested structures
   - probably no more than three levels deep in practice
   - can be presented to users like a breadcrumb trail?
 * Risk of infinite recursion (a container inside itself)
   - disallow it in the code?

Please criticise

issues.summary: Merging/pooling samples and sample extracts
issues.description:
It's become apparent that some samples (and in future sample extracts) will need to be merged/pooled into new samples (e.g. juice and wine). 

This is possibly via a "merge samples" process:
* takes a number of samples to be merged (one per row) 
* user inputs into each row the pooled-sample that each sample is merged into
  * could be done by a unique name/number that is only used for that process and thrown away when the new sample is created
  * could be done with a compulsory-unique alternate-id
* process identifies unique names from the pooled-sample names column then for each new pooled-sample:
  * create a new sample in the sample table
  * attach pooled-sample to it's parent samples via a recursive many-to-many


Example data sheet from users perspective:

| sample-name | volume | volume unit | pooled-sample-name |
| ------------- | -------- | ----------- | ---------------------- |
| sample 1        | 20          | ml                |  mix 1                            |
| sample 2        | 20          | ml                |  mix 1                            |
| sample 3        | 20          | ml                |  mix 1                            |
| sample 4        | 20          | ml                |  mix 2                            |
| sample 5        | 20          | ml                |  mix 2                            |
| sample 6        | 20          | ml                |  mix 2                            |
| sample 7        | 20          | ml                |  mix 2                            |

this would result in two new samples in the sample table and 7 new connections in the many-to-many table (which the user doesn't need to see).

Pros:
* Works for any sample type
* Can create mixtures of mixtures (I'm sorry)
* Uses existing UI elements = less friction for users
* Users doesn't need to see/understand the many-to-many table
* Similar implementation for samples and sample-extracts

Cons:
* yet more recursion to deal with
* a unique name/number is required for the pooled-sample *before* the sample is created but this can be done with a temporary name/number that is thrown away afterwards or stored as an alternate id

comments.body:
@zanejg 

A slightly simpler version would work if you wanted the process to result in only a single merged sample. This way you could avoid the issue of specifying a unique id before the sample is created.
E.g.:

| sample-name | volume | volume unit |
| ------------- | -------- | ----------- |
| sample 1        | 20          | ml                |
| sample 2        | 20          | ml                |
| sample 3        | 20          | ml                |

would create a single new pooled-sample
comments.author: tim.millar

comments.body: Yup, just about to start work on this... hopefully
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: can't update trialplots with upload
issues.description: We are getting a 500 error when trying to update trialplots via the spreadsheet upload.

comments.body:
OK... 
to reproduce this error download some trial-plots from the admin interface.
In the downloaded data file, move  the trials column to the correct position (see bug #351 )
Copy the data to the skeleton.

issues.summary: /var/log/keaapp needs to be owned by keaapp
issues.description:
Upon starting the containers we get these in the docker logs:

```
[root@wkokea21 ~]# docker ps
CONTAINER ID        IMAGE               COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                         PORTS                    NAMES
96ee14f17a36        322fcfd63570        "/app/deploy/docker/w"   23 seconds ago      Restarting (2) 8 seconds ago   0.0.0.0:8080->8080/tcp   kea_web_prod
7cc7407a9908        4fb558e8daa0        "/app/deploy/docker/c"   23 seconds ago      Restarting (2) 9 seconds ago                            kea_celery_prod
[root@wkokea21 ~]# docker logs 96ee14f17a36
/app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: 5: /app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: cannot create /app/var/log/django_migrate.log: Permission denied
/app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: 5: /app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: cannot create /app/var/log/django_migrate.log: Permission denied
/app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: 5: /app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: cannot create /app/var/log/django_migrate.log: Permission denied
/app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: 5: /app/deploy/docker/web/entrypoint.sh: cannot create /app/var/log/django_migrate.log: Permission denied
```

Looking at the Dockerfile, I can see that you are chowning the log directory as part of the Docker build:
https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/blob/master/deploy/docker/web/Dockerfile#L34

This would work when the container is built on the target host, but not when the container is pulled on a different one. Maybe `entrypoint.sh` (or perhaps as part of the ansible deployment playbook?) is a better place.

comments.body:
Hi Eric,

I am unable to access the aklkea22 server again. Perhaps it is the same problem as before? I can ssh into powerplant without any issues. Could you please have a look at this for me then I'll have a look at the issue.

Thanks,

William.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
I'm also not sure what difference chowning the directory after the image is built would make? Everything happens within the image so it wouldn't matter what host the image is run on

You mention ansible so are you referring to creating the directory on the host machine? In this case then yes it should be part of the ansible playbook. The playbook should create the directory /var/log/keaapp on the host and make sure it is chowned by keaapp.

/app/var/log should work in exactly the same way that /app/var/media and /app/var/static do.

issues.summary: Template fields when using a Foreign Key
issues.description:
### issue

In some contexts when a new entity is created, some of data is clearly inhered from an existing entity of the same type.

This data currently needs to be filled in by the user manually which is error prone and slow.

While this inherited information is implicit in the DB it is not displayed explicitly to the user an in special cases there may be real reason why the data is not inherited.

### example

An example of this is in the potato provenance when creating a new potato plant that is a child of a preexisting parent potato plant. 
In this case fields like "variety" should always be inherited.

technically this is implied by the parent-child relationship in the DB but this is not clear to the user and having the field automatically filled in is a good sanity check that the user has selected the correct parent plant.

A second example in potato is when a potato comes from a potato sac. The company/purported variety should be inherited from the sac

### feature

In a provenance models when defining foreign key (maybe via a TemplateForeignKey class) you can specify inherited/template fields as key-value pairs.
The data from those fields are then automatically filled out in the gui (but can be manually changed).

This may be simpler to implement only for recursive foreign keys.

This is the sort of work that would be good to do but would be a big job especially to make it reasonably generalised and hence reusable.

comments.author: tim.millar

comments.body:
Please note that the fix for this is just re-ordering the default renderer classes in the settings file.

The rest-framework library will go through the renderer classes in the order that they are defined and pick one based on best match. This is by checking things like the Accept header, querystring params etc.

I'm not sure if anyone is actually using the html interface to use the api (KeaBrowsableApiRenderer) but this change may make that particular renderer not available in the browser by default. So this "fix" is a trade off in usability as to what the default renderer should be.

So, knowing all of this you may or may not want to merge in this particular change. If you want further clarification please talk to me.
comments.author: will.buick

issues.summary: Cannonical 'terminate' option/button
issues.description:
We need to establish a canonical 'terminate' option for all entities which users can interact with.

Currently they have options to delete entities including specimens/samples/locations.
Deleting is OK if they create an entity that was a mistake, but not if the entity was real bu has been thrown out/died/etc.
As time goes on Kea will become full of entities that where real but have now been  'terminated'.
It's critical that these entities remain in the DB for the sake of auditing and if they are referenced by other entities (e.g. parent child relationships). 

To ensure that they don't get deleted and don't clutter up what the user sees we need to have a recycle bin type approach that will flag an entity as 'terminated' and hide it from UI elements (at least by default).

comments.body: Good idea
comments.author: zane.gilmore

issues.summary: Datagrid-like data entry
issues.description:
There are a few use cases emerging where someone has to routinely add a handful of entities to the DB that relate to one another. Doing this manually through the current website is slow and error prone.

It would be useful to have a datagrid-like UI element that can be set up for data entry.
I.e. something that we can code to take a set number of named  (and typed) input fields that can then be inserted into the DB via the ORM or as as a single transaction, this would allow for some level of functionality as described in  #476

issues.summary: Datagrid slow for biggish datasets
issues.description:
William,
We need to get this faster.
As far as I can tell it's not the SQL.
Although I have replaced everything to use the rawSQL backend there doesn't appear to be too much time being spent in the backend. (< 0.5 sec)
The datagrid is taking > 6 secs to respond and often > 20 secs.
Perhaps some profiling is required?
Could you please spend some time trying to characterise what needs to change?

comments.body:
That particular case is certainly one source of slowness but not the important one.

If someone is looking at the 100th page of a monstrous result set... don't care.

Go to the list process-runs page on Kiwifruit. ( process/processrun/search/ )
Even the first page is sloooow (~5secs) . 
And I don't think that that is being caused by the back-end.
But I could be convinced otherwise.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
A stab in the dark here. 
I cant remember the infrastructure of Kea completely, how difficult is it to set u a docker container running postgres next to kea restore a db and repeat the steps?
The increase in performance from Kakapo moving out of the shared database was enough for **users** to notice on the quick forms as well as clearing up some of the long running ones.

Lee,
It's probably easy for William to do this but running Postgres in a Docker container gives me the willies.
(this is probably not rational but I would need to be convinced that DB corruption etc would not be an problem)

But as I said earlier in this issue. I'm not convinced it's the DB stuff that's causing the sluggishness anyway. However perhaps we need to look at the available resources for the Postgres server etc.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
I agree Zane, initially I was concerned about dockerising to the db, however with the remote volume (actual data) on the host not the container it doesn't seem so bad. This also give you the flexibility to jump versions without testing/upgrading the other 8 systems on the shared host, 9.3 is getting old!

We really need someone to optimize the config on the pg servers. they are out of the box config from what I have seen, then have multiple high demand dbs on them...

23sec for 2000 rows doesn't sound good. Unless this is due to demoralization, then maybe you need to look at Cassandra or similar for the read model - a significant change though.

You're returning a dataset starting at page 2000. 50 results per page means that you have an offset of 100000. Using limit/offset queries in postgres is not an efficient way to paginate over large datasets. Postgres will actually look through the entire dataset until it gets to row 100000 and will return results starting there. This is the reason why it takes 20 seconds to return page 2000 and almost instant when you return page 1.

The big problem to switch to something like cassandra is that django (the framework that kea is built on) does not nicely support these type of databases.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
I have found the problem.

Please refer to the following file/line

kea/processes/views/processrun.py line 496

ProcessRun.objects.get(id = obj['id']).has_started_data_entry()

That is running quite a few database queries. So for every record that you are trying to render in the datagrid you are running several database queries. 

I'm not sure exactly how you want to solve this. Will need to discuss with you.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
So let's prioritise some particular datagrids.
Starting with the Sample search one
In the crop prov's please ensure that the genotypes and plants are as quick as easily possible.

When I get back we can discuss a better approach.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
I've done some benchmarking of postgres 9.4, 9.6 and 10 using the samples datagrid. Just by using a newer version of postgres you can see some significant speed increases.

Tests were completed using the kiwifruit crop and samples datagrid.

Loading last page in samples datagrid :

- 9.4 32 seconds
- 9.6 28 seconds
- 10 30 seconds

Order by plant local id (postgres stored function)

- 9.4 31 seconds
- 9.6 10 seconds
- 10  9 seconds

Search for plant localid (postgres stored function)

- 9.4 54 seconds
- 9.6 42 seconds
- 10 38 seconds

So this is an easy way to get more speed without changes to the codebase. I know it's not sub-second, but it's a speed improvement that you can easily get.

Please note that these times were taken when running postgres in a docker container in a development environment. It may be faster running on a more powerful machine and/or natively.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Code changes that will increase speed.

https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/commit/16a15ac2528af2ac62b73fc3d1ce0dba9987fc54

The important one is the change to getplantlocalid postgres function. You were running 3 select queries in that function that was getting data that you already had access to in the main select query. I changed the function to not do any select queries and pass all of the required values using function parameters. This increased the speed considerably, especially when filtering on that column.

I put the changed function into var/sql/getplantlocalid.sql - You may want to change the name of the function, however it should work just fine with the existing function with the same name because it has different arguments so shouldn't conflict.

Other changes include
- Added missing indexes
- Separate sql queries between provenance/crop samples to not include unnecessary tables in joins.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
I'm reasonably sure that this work has been added now.
Though we will always need to be vigilant for speed issues and try to speed things up as we go.

issues.summary: Add serial number to Dewar Tube locations
issues.description:
There are two 'numbers' given to Dewar Tubes (not including barcode or position).

When some tissue is put into cryo several (usually four) duplicates are made.
Each of the duplicates has the same **"Tube Number"** which identifies the set of replicates.
Each Tube within a set of replicates has a unique **"Serial Number"** which is used to separate each tube within the set (e.g. 1, 2, 3, 4).

"Tube number" is already included in the  Dewar Tube location but "Serial number" needs to be added.

comments.body: Has this been done?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: yes
comments.author: tim.millar

issues.summary: Process run results in proxy error on testing
issues.description:
I received this via email from Ana Claasen:

> Slipstream have completed kiwifruit sex testing for PFR and I am currently trying to upload results to Kea. I have been attempting to test the process (Sex screening into plate) in keatest.pfr.co.nz and I keep running into the error below when downloading an excel spreadsheet for the process.

![image jpg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14065102/32806582-e2f23c44-c9f1-11e7-860d-1215d66bc2a8.jpeg)

> Do you have any idea what might be causing the issue? Does this seem like an error that may be restricted to Kea test and not Kea actual? I'm not sure if they run on the same server.

comments.body:
There could be any number of different things causing this. Without actually being on site at PFR to debug this there isn't much that I can do I'm afraid.

If you can provide exact replication steps I could try to see if I can generate an error in my development environment, but because of differences between my dev env and keatest/prod this may not be possible.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
@timothymillar it could a be a reverse proxy timeout. Apache's default is 10 seconds. If the spreadsheet took longer than that to be generated, or if Kea took longer than that to start sending the data for Apache to proxy it, you would get a proxy error.

I found these in `/var/log/keaapp`:

```
uwsgi.log:[pid: 18|app: 0|req: 67199/112286] 172.17.0.1 () {46 vars in 1013 bytes} [Wed Nov 15 14:31:23 2017] GET /process/processrun/execute/1548/1548/XL/ => generated 26707 bytes in 172333 msecs (HTTP/1.1 200) 4 headers in 244 bytes (1 switches on core 2)
(...)
uwsgi.log:[pid: 18|app: 0|req: 70267/117379] 172.17.0.1 () {44 vars in 1088 bytes} [Thu Nov 16 11:55:11 2017] GET /process/processrun/execute/1548/1548/XL/ => generated 2581 bytes in 10137 msecs (HTTP/1.1 500) 3 headers in 130 bytes (1 switches on core 4)
uwsgi.log:[pid: 18|app: 0|req: 70269/117383] 172.17.0.1 () {48 vars in 1141 bytes} [Thu Nov 16 11:55:32 2017] GET /process/processrun/execute/1548/1548/XL/ => generated 2581 bytes in 10194 msecs (HTTP/1.1 500) 3 headers in 130 bytes (1 switches on core 3)
```

You can try increasing [ProxyTimeout](https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_proxy.html#proxytimeout) in `/etc/httpd/conf.d/kea.conf` and restarting apache.
comments.author: eric.burgueño

issues.summary: proxy error on processrun create spreadsheet
issues.description:
When trying to create a spreadsheet on a particular processrun we are getting a "Proxy Error":
```
Proxy Error

The proxy server received an invalid response from an upstream server.
The proxy server could not handle the request GET /process/processrun/execute/1548/1548/XL/.

Reason: Error reading from remote server
```
The process (id= 1588 on the test server) have about 4700 samples.
So I am thinking that we may have some sort of time-out problem with the docker container or similar.

comments.body:
Yes, that is exactly what this is

deploy/docker/web/run_web.sh needs to be changed

Try adding the --http-timeout=600 parameter

uwsgi --http-auto-chunked --http-keepalive --logto=/app/var/log/uwsgi.log 

becomes

uwsgi --http-auto-chunked --http-keepalive --logto=/app/var/log/uwsgi.log --http-timeout=600

Then push out a new release.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Did that and redeployed to test.
It did not work.
What about that healthcheck thing?
How does that work?
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: You also may need to adjust the proxy timeout on the apache side also.

comments.body: @timothymillar help me, what's missing?
comments.author: roy.storey

comments.body:
@kiwiroy It looks like you are using the wrong crop number 
> `http://kea.pfr.co.nz/api/crop/15`

Kiwifruit is crop 2 (It took me way too long to figure this out)

This works for me:
```
sample_container_url = '{}/crop/{}/sample-containers/'.format(api_url, 2)  # crop number = 2

search_params = {
    'LocalID': '1HP4',
}

resp = requests.get(sample_container_url, headers=headers, params=search_params)

data = resp.json()

print(json.dumps(data, indent=4))
```
comments.author: tim.millar

comments.body: Just so you're aware, permissions are tied to crops/provinence in Kea which will be why you need to specify the correct crop to pull data associated with that crop
comments.author: tim.millar

comments.body: superb.
comments.author: roy.storey

issues.summary: Attribute error in complex process create XL file
issues.description:
While executing a complex processrun:
"A.S. Wilcox May 2016"
Then clicking on the XL icon of the "Split extracts into Plate" just above "Pyruvate Chemical Assay"
I get:
[AttributeError at _process_processrun_execute_1114_1119_XL_.zip](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/files/4084149/AttributeError.at._process_processrun_execute_1114_1119_XL_.zip)
This works on the staging instance.

comments.body:
Just a quick note.
The line that I clicked the XL icon for was the highlighted one. (and should be for you if you are running a similar DB)
The others appear to work.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: Fixed!
comments.author: rodrigo.otero

comments.body:
First of all my apologies for not giving you the details required for this.
It is in the Onion crop, but it looks like you found it.

For these complex multi-step processes, as the user works their way down the process the step or steps that become the "current" step is highlighted light green.

Because a split is done on the samples, 2 steps become current because they can be done concurrently.
Yes you have fixed the problem I described but now that there are 2 current steps highlighted, neither of the new current Excel production buttons are working.
The "pyruvate" one is giving:
[TypeError at _process_processrun_execute_1114_1120_XL_.zip](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/files/4106561/TypeError.at._process_processrun_execute_1114_1120_XL_.zip)

And the "fructan" one is giving:
[AttributeError at _process_processrun_execute_1114_1121_XL_.zip](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/files/4106562/AttributeError.at._process_processrun_execute_1114_1121_XL_.zip)

Again, my apologies for not being very comprehensive with my description.
And if you need help understanding what is going on with this interface please feel free to ask.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: I have added a description of the multi-step processes to that wiki page [here](https://github.com/PlantandFoodResearch/Kea/wiki/Process-Decriptions)
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
Hi Zane
I've fixed the second one.

However the first error is produced because the parent SampleExtractProcess of the highlighted one has no nothing on its "Data" attribute. Is this a bug or is it possible to create a process without data?



![sample_extract_process](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5288675/73137806-e1df2580-403a-11ea-8e27-fbbafae94790.png)

![sample_extract_process2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5288675/73137807-e1df2580-403a-11ea-9b87-4a06e3772593.png)
comments.author: rodrigo.otero

comments.body:
Let's call sample[extract]process SEP it is one of the 2 many to many relations between sample ad ProcessRun. They hold the actual data as JSON that is defined by the "DataDefinition" JSON field in the Process column.

When the ProcessRun is initially set up the SEP has no data.
The data field is only populated when the spreadsheet is created.
And even then it is empty (I think it is "{}" )
Only when the spreadsheet is uploaded is there actual JSON data in the field.

Those getDataDict method calls should return None if there is no data for the sample[extract]process. 
Your question "is it possible to create a process without data?" 
The short answer is no for **Processes**. But a **ProcessRun** _can_ have no data.
ProcessRuns have no data when they are created.

After a quick rummage around it looks like extraneous SEPs are being produced when the user clicks on the Excel icon. If there is already data in the ProcessRun then a new spreadsheet should just be produced from the data without producing new SEPs.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
OK.
After a lot of rummaging around and setting pdb break points etc...

It appears that during our testing and debugging, a bunch of bad SEP rows were produced.
Maybe my transaction management is not so good or something similar but those bad SEP rows seem to have have been causing those problems.

After testing that Process against other ProcessRuns that were not involved with the original bugs, it looks like we are sweet :-)
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body: It should be the name of the foreign key field that links to the previous object in the chain.
comments.author: will.buick

comments.body:
Yeah.
Not good. It should be the name of the actual current object.
The way it is is just confusing.

BTW also getting the impression that providing the speciment to the endpoint would simplify things a whole lot and probably speed things up.
comments.author: zane.gilmore

comments.body:
I take it back. It is potentially useful to have the foreign-key name in that list.
However it should not be called  "relation".
In the DB world relation is another name for a table/model.
It needs to be renamed "foreign-key" or similar.
